piano theme with a few absolutely huge-sounding percussive hits. This

Afro-beat pioneer Fela Kuti was never more pissed off at his homeland's military government than in 1974. In that year
column2: the Nigerian police persistently raided his compound
column4: as a result of Kuti's growing public opposition to the ruling junta.  Having beaten     a narcotics charge
column5: the Lagos police swarmed Kuti's home in an attempt to plant a big fat joint on the premises and arrest him for possession.

column1: Quick in thought as well as funk
column2: Fela swallowed the joint.  The on-looking officers promptly     pushed him into the back of their wagon. Their immaculate plan was to wait for Kuti to dump     his morning load for proof.  They would then test the turd for THC and
column4: throw Kuti in the choky for a very long time
column5: effectively ridding the Nigerian     police of their number one gadfly.  Though raised in what might be termed a middle-class     environment
column6: Fela Kuti was very much a people's champion
column7: and his famous testing of authority was what saved him in the end-- he was able to exchange his stool for a less-enhanced specimen.

column1: Fela Kuti had been an attentive apprentice when he jammed with some of James Brown's band members in a Los Angeles recording studio in 1969. But sadly
column2: Kuti failed to secure the     proper work Visas
column4: the Immigration and Nationalization Service threw     him out of the country.  Of course
column5: Kuti had already gotten what he needed-- James Brown's     funk and some Black Panther literature. He would turn his old band into a JB's-style groove     machine
column6: re-name it the Africa 70
column7: and bring it on to the worms in power.

column1: 1975's Expensive Shit is paired on this new MCA reissue with He Miss Road
column2: another Kuti release from that same year.  The album's centerpiece
column3: lead-off and title     track was undoubtedly one of the most influential tracks to the Afro-beat movement
column4: and     to artists like the Talking Heads
column5: who experimented with similar tribal rhythms on Fear of Music and their landmark album
column6: 1980's Remain in Light. Its complex
column7: bongo-     centric percussion is tempered with funk guitar
column8: discordant piano
column9: and brass eruptions.     And when
column10: six minutes into the semi-improvisational
column11: instrumental jam
column12: Kuti awakens with     a yowl and begins his political rant

column1: ""Water No Get Enemy
column4: postulating the motion of water as a metaphor for human interaction and the     rhythms of society. The music is lighter-- almost poetic-- but no less moving.  After     these two extended
column6: in the form of Kuti's follow-up     album
column7: He Miss Road. The title track here is a less strident affair than either of the cuts off Expensive Shit. Lyrically
column8: Kuti comments on people's stupidity;     he mocks an incompetent lawyer for handing over his brief to the prosecution
column9: and tells     of a band that turns up at a colony for the blind and the deaf.  After a squall of noise
column10: a summery
column11: psychedelic groove settles the mood until finally giving way to an ambient organ.

column1: Fela's tenor saxophonist
column3: surpasses all his other performances on this disc     during ""Monday Morning in Lagos
column4: which is up there with the Kinks' ""Waterloo Sunset"" for magical evocations of cities. Chico's glimmering lines perfectly represent the rays of the rising sun while Kuti's Yoruban vocals add the necessary otherworldliness to the track.

column1: The disc closes as it begins-- with bombs. On ""It's No Possible
column2: drummer Tony Allen     imposes a polyrhythmic torrent that locks in the rest of the Africa 70. They have no     choice but to grab hold of the music and further jazz it up.  Fela's lyrics denouncing     those who break promises effectively counterpoint Africa 70's joyous riot of uplifting     funk. But then
column3: that was Fela. Always contradictory-- a champion of women's rights who kept a harem of dozens of girls (pictured on the front cover of Expensive Shit). But there's no denying the guy's blatant courage in the eye of government
column4: or the legacy of his musical vision.

column1: With DJs steadily picking up on Francois Kervorkian's championing of Fela Kuti's work

it's all too easy to get caught up in Kuti's discography. Start with Expensive Shit and don't miss the road onward.

of fuzz that will leave you craving the kind-hearted fun of ""I Want You to Die.""

Will Oldham's Guarapero/Lost Blues 2 is more a precious pile of scraps than it is a great album. The collection of singles includes live and recorded work garnered from b-sides and compilation tracks
column2: as well as unreleased material.  In other words
column3: this is not Oldham's Sgt. Pepper. In fact
column4: it's more akin to ""The Collected Letters of Emily Dickinson;""     fragments
column5: which are valuable primarily in their relation to other work. Together
column6: these pieces grant a bit more access into the open wound of Oldham's dark but sober poetic vision.

column1: Lost Blues 2 recalls Roland Barthes' account of sorting through piles of family photographs in his seminal text
column2: ""Camera Lucida."" His search for a photograph that marked the     essence of photography became conflated with a search for his dead mother
column3: as he discovered ""that rather terrible thing which is there in every photograph: the return of the dead."" Barthes did find the photograph that invoked both his dead mother's presence and the defining essence of photography. He refers to this image as ""the wintergarden photograph.""

column1: The remnants of Lost Blues to sort through are diverse in quality and style as they span the course of seven years. ""The Risen Lord
column2: a D.H. Lawrence poem sung over a weak drum     machine beat and synthy organs doesn't produce the creepy tension you'd expect Oldham to pull     off in such an unlikely juxtaposition.  Live recordings of ""For the Mekons et al
column4: but show off some of Oldham's least restrained singing. ""Gesundheit""     starts off relaying
column5: ""I dreamed I saw Phil Ochs last night/ Alive as you or me
column6: before heading into a tape collage that ranges between a religious children's tape and a soundscape reminiscent of Angelo Badalamenti's ""Twin Peaks"" soundtrack.

column1: Lost Blues 2 isn't greater than the sum of its parts. It inspired thoughts of Emily Dickinson and French photographic wounds-- how rock is that? Those uninitiated into the Oldham/ Palace canon would be better off picking up a copy of the Palace Brothers' Viva Last Blues or Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy's I See a Darkness. If you get dragged in deeper
column3: Oldham's high-strung and sublime ode to terror. But for others of you-- and you know who you are-- Lost Blues 2 is an irresistible bundle of odd and ends which has the potential to contain that note or phrase which unsettles. Or rather
column4:
it's just another record in which you might find your wintergarden photograph.

Organicity in popular music has been greatly complicated by the advent of
electronica.  The fact that pop and rock are principally derived from the
organic unity of several instruments combining to create a singular sound
is rendered moot by the reality that electronic music begins with organic
unity as an immediate instance of synchronicity.  So one could posit the
viewpoint that the attempt to create organic unity in electronic music is
pointless.
Of course
column2: electronic music has caused something of a viral infection in

column1: pop music. Whereas before it was content to keep pace with digital media and
exercise developmental innovation in the processing of sound
now begun to appropriate the intent of pop.  The role of guitar as an organic
cog-in-the-wheel has died
column2: and pop music has since begun to resemble a cyborg.

column1: DAT Politics is a laptop quartet from Lille
column2: France.  An offshoot of the much

column1: whispered about French post-rock group Tone Rec (of which three of these four
guys are members)
column2: Villiger is their second album of sharp

column1: arranged electronic product.  It's an amazing picture of where electronica
and pop music meet
column2: a jaw-droppingly consistent instance of glitchy electronics

column1: and massively processed tones wedded to a more traditional musical heritage.
The band applies a more populist approach to the groundbreaking static
orchestrations exemplified by Mego artists like Fennesz and Pita without
diluting the sonic edge of the work.  The four members interact and bounce
ideas off one another relentlessly
column2: using shards of overheated electronics to

column1: sculpt a profoundly melodic musical interplay.
The tracks range from miniature exercises in digital sound processing to
full-blown beat-driven electro-pop songs
column2: each track blazing its own stylistic

column1: trail as it develops.  On one track
column2: they manage to evoke a horn section

column1: tripping over a distinct melodic theme.  The song's subsequent breakdown even
seems to approximate something like what George Martin might produce if locked
up in the BBC Radiophonic Workshop.
Villiger is the heavy-handedness of experimental music skillfully
tempered by a refreshingly engaging approach.  DAT Politics provide a vibrant
fusion of electronic music with a pop sensibility without sacrificing the
edge of its musical process.  That their work is the product of an organic
group dynamic lends this album its immediacy and verve.  Two members of Tone
Rec have recently abandoned guitar and bass for notebook computers.  As it

should be.

In the Beta Band's hotel room a collage sat unfinished on the faux-wood table. The piece
depicted Europe with substituted country names and surreal clippings. Scandinavia was dubbed
""Cock & Balls""; Switzerland was noted only for their chocolate. Humorous cut-and-paste crafts
aren't typical rock 'n' roll hotel room behavior. Yet after hearing the Beta Band
is expected. It's reassuring to step behind the curtain and realize the giant talking head of
the wizard is actually a giant talking wizard's head. The Beta Band really do live in their
pastiche pastures and carry Dada handbags. Their new stand-alone single proves they're still
burning fuel past escape velocity-- they effortlessly surpass their peers with two seemingly
simple songs.
""To You Alone"" opens with a bellowing bass pulse and tantric humming before stuttering into
epileptic beats and a plaintive keyboard melody. The song punches a hole through the back of
TLC's ""No Scrubs""
column3: and reconstructs an interstellar psychedelic booty call.

column1: Further blurring the line between dance
an 808 blurt out hair-raising space-pop. A crescendo of drums pile up during the chorus.
Steve Mason weaves a unique take on unrequited love with his longing lyrics. ""You do not realize
the line that runs from me across the universe to you alone
doom of the one-way relationship is wonderfully wrapped in the metaphor: ""A black box inside my
mind recalls the time we spend together."" Finally
column2: he proclaims in a mix of pride and resignation

column1: ""I'm gonna sing it like a fool/ I've been singing like a fool.""  The Beta Band's ability to touch
on such emotions while simultaneously expanding pop music's vocabulary justifies every ounce of
hype surrounding them.
""Sequinsizer"" provides more of an instrumental funk. The nocturnal urban pulse blends Aphex
Twin's ""Windowlicker"" and Primal Scream's ""Swastika Eyes"". A clarinet drifts over basslines
that rocket like metro lines. Fat keyboards make the groove positively nasty. With a single
track
column2: the Beta Band offhandedly outdate everything Underworld pumped out in the last couple

column1: years. If Miles Davis worked with Warp Records
On this single
column2: the Beta Band recontextualize hip-hop and city rhythms into their sylvan

column1: fantasy planet. You can take Mos Def
Monch-- you can find him ""keeping it real"" on the new Scritti Politti record.  When it comes
to futuristic hip-hop-- and rock for that matter-- I'd rather place my bets on these four

scruffy Scots.

column3: casual music listener who changes radio stations if     something blatantly ear-throttling (or vulgarly romantic) isn't playing!     That's what I say.  These unfortunate souls-- and I think we all know a     handful-- will never quite grasp what it is that makes the rest of us so     enamored of the work of Pan American's Mark Nelson

column1: Patience is a virtue. The Best Things Come to Those Who Wait. Ah
column2: which     cliché shall I evoke next?  Tempting as it may be for Mr. Casual Listener
column4: to dismiss music that takes its time to get going
column5: he does it a great disservice by actually doing so. Nelson revels in the small details-- the subtle shifts in texture and sound.

column1: When recording with his creepy Virginian avant-o-mates in Labradford
column2: Nelson     concentrates on instrumental interplay in pieces that are simultaneously     soothingly static and unsettling.  But when left to his solo devices
column3: we find Pan American notching out the more dub-influenced groove sensibilities that lingered in some of Labradford's work. It's been said that Lab-mate Carter Brown's more typical muso approach to composition tempers Nelson's electronics- descended leanings. That argument is given credence here on this second-- and quite remarkable-- album under Nelson's Pan American moniker.

column1: All manner of vaguely eerie atmospheres abound on this record
column2: yet for     all the surface iciness
column3: there's a beckoning textural warmth that keeps     it from sounding distant.  With headphones
column4: the craft of the sonics is more     readily absorbed-- at wimpy low levels
column5: this stuff would probably be     about as interesting as listening to distant street traffic.  But
column6: as     anyone who's truly had their ass kicked by great music knows
column7: volume gets     results.  Quickly.  Turn this shit up if it isn't rocking your boat
column8: in other     words.  Only then will the lovely clanging and dubby bass of ""Double Rail""     nail all the right places in your little black heart.  At low levels
column9: guest vocalists Low and backing music on ""Code"" could be mistaken for     some crazy religious radio station with some worrisome repeated chanting.     Up goes the listening level
column10: and you're being grooved along thusly by the     pounding kicks
column11: ringing dub-rhythmic chords and echoed hats and cymbals
column12: while the rather lovely minor-key chant drills itself into your brain.

column1: Nelson's work here is not too derivative in itself
column2: but traces of artists     like Pole
column4: and the Basic Channel/Chain Reaction     stable are in attendance.  Here and there
column5: Nelson goes on auto-pilot for     a little too long: ""Coastal"" seems a bit too content to ride a vaguely     lovely but ultimately too-featureless pattern to its inevitable end several     minutes later.  Bits of ""K. Luminate"" meander
column6: which is understandable over the course of a nine or ten minute track.

column1: The addition of Chicago Underground Duo cornetist Rob Mazurek would seem to be a nice avant touch to the otherwise electronic tracks
column2: but it works     better on paper than on the record.  His playing
column3: while a warm complement     at times
column4: usually sticks out like a sore thumb. It seems particularly forced     into unlikely spots on the closer
column6: a track which otherwise     follows another savory recipe of deep bass
column7: echoing percussion
column8: and laidback chordal repetition.

column1: All in all
column2: chalk up another worthy and fascinating chapter to Kranky's     already formidable post-rock/experimental catalogue.  Come
column4: pray with me and my congregation at the Sonic Altar in the     Church of Studio Wizardry
column5: won't you?  We're a fine bunch
column6:
once you get to know us.

Some things you have to be in the mood for. Personally
column2: I am never in the mood for egg salad.

column1: Occasionally
column2: I am in the mood for Stockhausen's Helicopter Quartet (the one where each

column1: member of a string quartet is aloft in a helicopter and skronking out bizarre musique concrete
accompanied by the drone and swoop of rotorblades!). I am rarely in the mood for exotica. And
Stop the Panic
The project all started when electro-acoustic egghead David Toop and veteran pedal steel
guitarist BJ Cole were yakking on about Les Baxter
column2: Yma Sumac and the other luminaries of

column1: that 50's bachelor pad sound. Toop had just published his book on the subject and was filled
with the promise that what Stereolab
column3: and Broadcast had been achieving with their fusion

column1: of exotica and Krautrock could also be accomplished in the electronic avant-garde. Toop played
Cole some Plug discs and Cole decided that Wagon Christ himself
beatnik he wished to get all gaudy and South Sea Islander with. Ugh!
Stop the Panic
column3: is not geared for a Tiki Hut experience. I'd feared that

column1: Vibert would churn out 13 versions of that wretched ""Lovely"" track that so marred his <i>Tally
Ho! record. Though Cole runs through the primer on the Hawaiian glide and the Nashville
glissando
column2: Vibert's straight-ahead beats cut the cheese to a tolerable minimum.

column1: As Cole blithely swoops and curls his pedal steel line on ""Dischordzilla
rhythmic slabs like he's trying to crush his collaborator. ""Cheng Phooey"" begins life as a
low-rumbling 303 line before releasing a venomous burst Polynesian acid. Cole's reaction--
to use his pedal steel as a machine of avant tonal color
column2: as if wishing to wash away the

column1: spikes of the bassline. All of this recalls Cole's work with Billie Ray Martin (""4 Ambient
Tales"") and starkly demonstrates that the pedal steel associations with beach huts and
Nashville can be rent asunder.
The duo pay another quick visit to the Land of Shriekin' N' Hollerin' on ""Watery Glass Planet
(Part 3)"" and
column3: the pair manage to heighten the gracious beauty of the

column1: pedal steel guitar by placing it in an atypical setting. There's a palpable watery glassiness
to Cole's solos and Vibert deftly sets Cole's shimmering lines in just the right subtly spacy
frame.
It's clear that Vibert and Cole haven't jumped on this project as an opportunity to wank
around. These talented musicians have considered the profound complexities (and negotiated the
fault lines) inherent in exotica. So the big pay off of Stop the Panic is that Cole and
Vibert manage to subvert the genre without shoving its most gangrenous aspects in our faces. It
was no accident that during the culturally repressed and globally paranoid 1950's
market became susceptible to sanitized
column2: surreal images of the peoples who lived in steamy

column1: aboriginal or Communist climes.  Exotica was the pop culture banalization of the First World
condescension of Joseph ""The Impenetrable"" Conrad.   It was such a weird time-- I mean
other point in history would a new design of bathing suit was named in honor of a Pacific atoll
that had just been cored by the test of a U.S. A-bomb?  Yes
column2: the bikini is a memento of First

column1: World entitlement.  Wear yours with pride!
David Toop understands all the cultural resonances within the exotica genre
have listened well to his sherpa-like guidance. Stop the Panic-- I hope-- will be the
last word on this fusion of the avant-garde and the lei. However
column2: a sinking feeling nags at me

column1: and reminds me that the Stormtroopers of Marketing will surely seize this album and demand
a truckload of tiki-ready platters from far less conscientious musicians.  In fact
panicking now
column2: if I were you-- but that's just the mood I'm in.

Obviously
column2: Will Oldham wasn't thinking of the music criticism world when he decided to

column1: release the Ode Music EP. He was probably most concerned with fulfilling the
New Year's Resolution he seems to have made way back in 1993.  You know the one I'm
talking about. That year
column2: Will Oldham began competing with such corporate giants as the

column1: ""Book of the Month Club"" and the ""Fruit of the Month Club"" by unofficially creating the
""Will Oldham Release of the Month Club.""  Since then
more monikers than most bands have songs: Palace (Brothers/Music/Songs)
Billy
column4: to name just a few.  He's been true to

column1: his convictions thus far
records at a frantic pace nonetheless.
The Ode Music EP is a particularly confounding case to examine. On one hand
can't fault him too much
column2: because he never intended for the album to stand alone--  it was

column1: composed as an instrumental soundtrack to the Kelly Reichardt film of the same name.  In
that regard
column2: it succeeds admirably.  I imagine that this music would be quite a pleasant

column1: addition to any movie with ""Ode"" in the title.  On the other hand
upset with Oldham.  Somehow
column2: he's managed to get his hands on the first five songs I ever

column1: wrote for guitar back in High School.  Frankly
column2: I'm a bit embarrassed.  To make matters

column1: worse
column2: I'm not mentioned anywhere in the liner notes.

column1: The five unique songs on Ode Music are so incredibly simple
inclined to believe me upon actually hearing the album.  Allow me to list the chords
Oldham demonstrates a thorough mastery of on ""Ode #1
And it's probably just a C with a capo on the first fret
doesn't stop demonstrating this proficiency for almost eight minutes.  And that's not
even mentioning the two negligibly different reprises of the song which also appear
on the EP. Ode Music is like Will Oldham's acoustic guitar version of house
music: each composition is comprised of one basic short riff in either one or two chords
repeated into infinity with almost no variation.  After a minute or so
forget that you're even listening to music at all.
Regardless of the music's redundancy
column3: it's still quite beautiful in its simplicity.

column1: Ode Music utilizes not only guitar
column2: but also sparse piano and synthesizer.  After all

column1: the primary goal of the record was to create a soothing atmosphere
off guard while listening to this EP.  Once you've heard the first 15 seconds of each song
you've basically heard the entire thing.
Despite the sheer volume of material he's issued in recent years
create a few stunning albums. I See a Darkness
is such an extraordinary piece of work that I was initially tempted to conveniently forget
to say much about Ode Music in this review and simply praise Darkness instead.
After all
column2: there's not much substance behind Ode Music to examine; it's just a whole

column1: lot of quantity.  But don't despair-- there are still about 50 better Oldham releases out

there worth scooping up.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/198/homepage_large.cd603690.jpg|Designing a Nervous Breakdown|100.0|The Anniversary|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vagrant']|2000-01-25 00:00:00||2016-06-11 22:00:36.130402|"

Right now
column2: I'm eating a Pop Tart.  I highly recommend this activity.  For the most part

column1: the Pop Tart is quite a delicious toaster pastry
column2: replete with tasty frosting and sticky

column1: filling.  But sadly
column2: the Pop Tart is not without its ailments.  The first of these is the

column1: Crust Problem-- for every delectable
column3: one must also endure an equal

column1: number of bites sullied by what is mostly flavorless crust.  The discerning Pop Tart
enthusiast will go to such lengths as to actually eliminate all crust-only zones before
attempting the more flavorful middle area.  This is something of a pain.  The second problem
is the Unnecessary Multiplicity Problem
column2: which is that Pop Tarts are packaged in groups of two.

column1: In order to maximize freshness
column2: one must eat both at once or risk a stale Pop Tart.  Except in

column1: rare occasions
column2: the marginal utility of the second Pop Tart is greatly diminished to the point

column1: of seeming bland
column2: as its consumption is a totally identical experience to the previous Pop

column1: Tart.
The Anniversary's Designing a Nervous Breakdown is quite like a package of 10 Pop
Tarts; it flourishes and fails in the same capacities.  Upon listening to the first track
one is immediately struck by its sugary sweet goodness.  Still
mentally trimming away some of the blander passages in order to more greatly enjoy the really
good parts
column2: in a fashion similar to the Crust Problem.  The Unnecessary Multiplicity Problem

column1: also crops up
column2: as every one of the 10 songs is nearly indistinguishable from the last.  Same

column1: guitar distortion.  Same harmonies.  Same emo lyrics.  Same moog.  Sure
delicious
column2: but after eating virtually the same Pop Tart a few times

column1: irritate your stomach
column2: no matter how palatable they initially seem.

column1: Sonically
column2: the Anniversary is an interesting amalgam of pop styles.  Do you remember

column1: ""Friends of P"" by the Rentals?  Yes
column2: the one with the ultra-catchy moog riff in the

column1: chorus that was impossible to banish from your head
column2: as much as it embarrassed you to

column1: be humming oscillating octaves.  Don't make degrading jokes about that riff around the
Anniversary-- they won't laugh.  The Anniversary really enjoyed that song.  At least
enough to include the exact same kind of moog riff in literally every song on
Designing a Nervous Breakdown. Add equal parts 80's New Wave and slightly
derivative punk-ish chord progressions reminiscent of the best moments of early
Blink 182 (which are not many) and you have the foundation for virtually any Anniversary
song.  The opening guitar parts for both ""All Things Ordinary"" and ""The D in Detroit"" are
almost absolutely identical
column2: down to the same chords.  And the two are only one song

column1: apart. They could have at least changed key!
But despite the obnoxiously prominent similarities between each song on <i>Designing a
Nervous Breakdown
column2: the format from which they mold the songs is still rather tasty.

column1: Much like a savory Pop Tart
column2: I plan to consume the Anniversary again in the future

column1: not in vast quantities at one time. What a shame that Designing a Nervous Breakdown
isn't also an excellent source of 7 vitamins and minerals
Perhaps it would enhance the appeal of future Anniversary discs if they offered a variety
pack
column2:
hopefully including a ""S'mores"" flavor. Just an idea.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/13210/homepage_large.4e8528a5.jpg|Peregrine|3158.0|Tara Jane O'Neil|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Quarterstick']|2000-01-18 00:00:00||2016-06-11 22:00:36.744637|"

It snowed here in Williamsburg
column2: Virginia for the first time in years today.  Flurries were the

column1: forecast
column2: but they soon turned to showers
column3: covering the brick walkways that pass between the

column1: 17th century buildings. On this first day of snow-- the first true day of Winter in this
section of the Atlantic coast in ages-- I sit with the thermostat cranked 85 degrees high
listening to the new album from Tara Jane O'Neil.
I'm sure some of you recognize this name
column2: and even more recognize such band names as Rodan

column1: Retsin
column3: bands O'Neil has worked with in the past. With flakes easing past

column1: my window
column2: I feel an affinity for O'Neil and her first true solo album

column1: not for reasons you may think.
According to the liner notes
column2: this entire album-- instrumentation and songwriting-- was recorded

column1: by Tara in her New York City apartment. A brief outline of the many tools she uses includes
piano
column4: and thumb piano. This complex arrangement should be an immediate

column1: red alert to the ambitiousness of the album. While the songs are restrained to the point of
being timid
column2: a close listen to the album's empty space shows just how aggressive and engaging

column1: her songwriting can be.
O'Neil's voice is strong
the reverb and ring of electric and acoustic guitars.  Sparingly used double-tracked vocals
help emphasize themes of lost hope and despair. I realize this may sound obnoxious to some
but after two or three listens I began to look forward to lines that made me cringe the first
time through.
Although the volume of the album remains constant
column2: O'Neil moves in many different directions

column1: stylistically. ""A City in the North"" is reminiscent of the Cowboy Junkies' Trinity Sessions
a relaxed piece of melancholy lament. Its companion piece
the tone of a Carter Family waltz on a hungover Sunday morning. ""Asters"" alternates between the
manic train rhythms of Captain Beefheart and a cowgirl ballad cooed around a campfire.
But considering the circumstances around the album
column2: the range of styles feels out of place. The

column1: problem is not the monstrous sonic differences between Rodan and O'Neil's post-Rodan work. That's
an issue that most fans of the early 90's Midwest sound have had to deal with (think of King Kong
or the For Carnation). The problems with Peregrine are the contradictions it creates based
upon the arrangements that O'Neil chooses.
First off
column2: let's talk about the rural tone of an album recorded New York City. This music is

column1: for summer nights on the back porch shucking corn somewhere in the Midwest
for change in front of a ghetto McDonald's. Another strange aspect of Peregrine is how
aggressive the lyrics are in their claustrophobic and intimate content. The subject matter
of O'Neil's lyrics doesn't usually match the way she sings them
connected
On the surface
column2: Peregrine is a beautiful album. ""Sunday Song"" is an absolutely gorgeous

column1: cut whose acoustic guitars chime under a chorus in which O'Neil's voice is particularly strong.
On the other hand
column2: there's an adherence to standards of sorts. Whether it's country rock or the

column1: post-rock wanking of ""Flash Thumb Blues
column2: the music serves to keep the meaning on a very basic

column1: level.
The disorientation I felt seeing snow here in eastern Virginia is the same sensation I've had
trying to examine this album. The conventions that I would expect from Tara Jane O'Neil have
been pushed to the margins in favor of extreme simplicity.  She's describing gritty
yellow snow
column2: but covers it with a lily white blanket.  And while the surface still looks

column1: beautiful
column2:
the elements underneath prove too cluttered to make a snow angel.

have succeeded at creating a very nice

There are a few things you should know about this disc right off the bat:
1. The only color represented on either the cover art or the CD itself is a
particularly melancholy shade of blue. The disc itself has no writing or
identifying marks on it at all
2. The seventh song on Chappaquiddick Skyline is entitled ""Theme to
an Endless Bummer."" This could just as well have been the album title.
3. The first words out of Joe Pernice's mouth on the opening track
Else is Evolving"" are: ""I hate my life.""
Yes
column2: this is the latest installment of Joe Pernice's terminally-depressed

column1: orchestral pop musings
column2: and as if you haven't already gathered

column1: is a downer. Someone needs to give this guy a hug before he jumps
off a building.
You might have thought that the Pernice Brothers' Overcome by Happiness
was in need of a good dose of Prozac
column2: but that disc is positively sunny in

column1: disposition compared to this latest effort. And the fact is
definitely knows what he's doing-- these songs'll tug at your heartstrings
as impatiently as any sad song ever penned.  However
Pernice's past efforts-- whether with the Pernice Brothers (the lineup of which
is virtually the same as Chappaquiddick Skyline
his first group
column2: the underrated Scud Mountain Boys-- have always included at

column1: least a few up-tempo tracks to alleviate the gloom.  Not so here.  And it
wouldn't even be so bad
column2: except that the album is also sadly lacking in

column1: Pernice's beautiful ethereal vocal melodies
Happiness so plentifully.
With the exception of the cover of New Order's ""Leave Me Alone
on Chappaquiddick Skyline drags its feet. Too many of these songs float
by on nothing more than a breathy Pernice vocal and a chiming guitar progression.
This lends the album a breezy
column3: but it also leaves the listener

column1: precious little to sink teeth into.  Tracks like ""The Two of You Sleep"" and
""Knights of the Night Volume 1"" sound like half-baked demos. It doesn't help
that Pernice's vocal style is so deliberate that you can practically see him
enunciating each word.  Sadness and pain resonate in his voice
as if that he's so bummed that he feels like he can't afford to let a little
personality show through.
On a more positive note
column2: there are a few songs here that replicate the standard

column1: Pernice formula with quite a bit of success. ""Courage Up"" and ""Hundred Dollar
Pocket"" are both examples of Pernice at his best-- lilting melodies
arrangements and thoughtful (if still pretty depressing) lyrics. However

It's unclear whether Pernice has shelved the Pernice Brothers moniker in favor

column2: or if this is just a side project that utilizes many

column1: of the same players he usually works with.  If the side project scenario is
accurate
column2: he can certainly be forgiven this slight misstep. After all

column1: disc had been recorded by a no-name with no previous recordings to judge by
would probably be much more forgiving in my judgment.  However
Pernice doesn't quite live up to his legacy
column2: and what I and many others know he's

column1: eminently capable of.  Here's hoping he's feeling a touch more motivated next

Chicago Public Television runs a children's program on Summer afternoons called ""The Homework

column1: Show.""  Rather questionable marketing decisions lurk behind that.  Should we slip 'n' slide or
witness a desperate DePaul drama grad carry the zero?  ""The Homework Show"" is like showing
Die Hard 2 on a flight to Dulles. It's like a rib joint in the West Bank. It's like
Arab on Radar in your ears.
While they've successfully nudged the guitar a few steps closer to dentistry tools
Radar pound on the same bathroom-stall joke for 19 minutes on Soak the Saddle. The
opening track chugs away like a Brainiac knock-off in a combine
microphones made of a tin cans and yarn.  The result is neither menacing or powerful.  Crusty
drums jackhammer. Guitars whistle like tea is ready. It's shrill and calculated.
Though it may be considered punk in some circles to aggravate the listener
to charge people money for it.  This relentless grind and screech could suffice as passable
garage scrape-core if coupled with an intelligent
on Radar seemingly employs a congested Jon Lovitz reading the men's room graffiti in Bard's
student union.
""Nice girls don't soak the saddle/ Judy Garland doesn't use tampons
for home runs/ Hard-ons are unamerican.""  Each slogan is spat with such uninspired contempt that
the tone is difficult to discern.  Is ""the quality of bedwetting is conflict"" humor?  Is ""his
nuts inflate like a blowfish"" a mockery of modern Maxim masculinity? Probably not when
backed with a line like
column2: ""Have you ever seen a teenager with a package quite like that?""  Potty

column1: humor it is
column2: then. Let's not discuss the homosexual shower rape song.

column1: To make it ""art
column2: Arab on Radar title their songs ""1
column10: 9.""  And in further attempts

column1: to be difficult
column2: the tracks are sequenced in a different order!  Brilliant!  Bands like the

column1: Jesus Lizard and U.S. Maple have already done this with sincerity.  Orifice obsession and trashy
noise may get you big in Rhode Island
column2: but those unrelated to the band will be unimpressed at best.

column1: Perhaps parents can get their tots in front of the set for ""The Homework Show"" by threatening

them with Soak the Saddle on repeat.

Contrary to the beliefs of many middle-American supermarket-goers
column2: not all     samples are free.  Just ask Vanilla Ice.  When he ""sampled"" the bassline     from Queen and David Bowie's ""Under Pressure
column3: he was faced with a     multi-million dollar lawsuit
column4: rather than a complementary napkin and     toothpick.  Sure
column5: nobody bats an eye when copyright law takes some money out     of the shiny
column6: rhinestone-encrusted pockets of Rob Van Winkle or Puff Daddy
column7: but as soon as lawsuits trip up avant-hoodlums like John Oswald of     Plunderphonics fame
column8: the concept of thievery-as-art becomes a hot topic
column9: and the line between sampling and stealing becomes fiercely contended.

column1: Given the fact that Since I Left You
column2: the debut album from Aussie party     animals the Avalanches
column4: it's pretty     incredible that this thing got released in the first place.  The fact that     they sample everything from long-forgotten R&B; records to golf instructionals     to Madonna's ""Holiday"" makes it even more impressive.  But what really makes     this album brilliant is not as much the volume or quality of the samples used     as the way that they're employed. The Avalanches have managed to build a     totally unique context for all these sounds
column5: while still allowing each to     retain its own distinct flavor.  As a result
column6: Since I Left You sounds like nothing else.

column1: Much of the beauty of the opening title song and its accompanying track
column3: lies in the way that the Avalanches turn obvious sonic     mismatches into something all their own. It's not too common that you'll     hear a sample of a horse
column5: and an invitation to a Club     Med disco all in the same song
column6: but somehow it makes perfect sense under the masterful direction of the Avalanches.

column1: Indeed
column2: many of the most interesting moments on Since I Left You come with these mismatches. ""A Different Feeling"" sets horn blasts from 1974 against video game sounds from 1988-- the kind of bizarre pairing of classic soul with futuristic sounds that constitutes a substantial part of Avalanches magic. ""Radio
column3: which is slated for release as the band's next Australian single
column4: centers around a mantra-like vocal sample
column6: and bits and pieces of filtered guitars and synthesizers.

column1: Throughout Since I Left You
column2: sampled vocals are used almost like     percussion. But rather than utilizing the frenetic
column3: intricate rhythms seen in     most contemporary rap
column4: the Avalanches repeat small vocal samples over and over     again
column5: melding them into their rump-rocking grooves.  And while many of these     songs rely heavily on the repetition of beats and samples
column6: no single part of     the record is allowed to stagnate. Something is always being mixed up-- a     sample transposed up or down a few steps
column7: a beat chopped up into little pieces     and seamlessly restructured
column8: an unexpected vocal sample popping up out of nowhere before being swallowed up by the massive sound the Avalanches have concocted.

column1: Another key element of Since I Left You is the keen sense of humor the Avalanches display throughout. And ""Frontier Psychiatrist
column2: one of two singles     already released from the album
column3: is simply one of the funniest songs I've heard     in ages. Relying on a heavy
column5: ""Frontier     Psychiatrist"" busts out samples from 37 spoken word recordings
column6: resulting in     an oddball
column7: hilarious pastiche of phrases like
column8: ""You're a nut! You're crazy in the coconut!"" And some brilliant scratching on a sample of a parrot.

column1: Though it contains many distinct songs and moods
column2: Since I Left You is a remarkably coherent record on all fronts. Aside from the fact that the Avalanches achieve a certain uniform ""sound"" on this album
column3: subtler elements     come into play as well. Songs blend seamlessly into one another. Samples     reappear from song to song. And the album's final cut
column5: with     its breezy flute and psychedelic swells of sound
column6: puts a brilliant twist on     the album's title track
column7: fading out with that same chipmunky voice lamenting
column8: ""I've tried but I just can't get you/ Ever since the day I left you.""

column1: In releasing Since I Left You
column2: the Avalanches have essentially brought     hundreds of slabs of inanimate vinyl to life. Though it was no doubt     meticulously constructed
column3: this is an album brimming with spontaneity
column6: humor
column7: reflection
column8: and general human-ness. With its high fun factor     and subtle traces of deeper emotion
column9: Since I Left You is the perfect record for the party
column10:
and for the period of regret and recovery after the party.

At some point in 1998 I was standing alone in a triangular bar watching Les Savy Fav pound
away. Their show was unannounced. I luckily stumbled across the club's listing that morning
at work in ""Creative Loafing."" I'd been yearning to witness Les Savy Fav's live show
had been garnering disciples along the upper industrial coast. And there I was
Savy Fav were essentially playing just for me. Typically this scenario would be embarrassing--
a band outnumbering the crowd-- but Les Savy Fav rocked like I was Budokon.
Tim Harrington
stepped off the stage to sing in my face. His eyes bulged with fervent adrenaline in a near
thyroid- deficient manner. One guitarist stepped off the stage and flanked me. This band
with the audacity and zeal to rock an audience of one (not including the bar staff who were
wiping up in back)
column2: instantly won my heart. They worked up a sweat for me. They stormed the

column1: vault in my brain where I keep my favorite bands
column2: awoke some slumbering old-timers with slaps

column1: and kicked some undeserving squatters out the ear.
Most reviews of Les Savy Fav inevitably mention the band's live show. On one hand
demonstrates the band's stage dominance
column2: but it also points to the fact that their two LPs

column1: to date have been unable to capture that intensity.  This is not to say the albums haven't
been vital slabs of modern American punk. More so it reveals the effects of the modern digital
age on the underground.  Pro-Tools and CDs have spoiled the rural and suburban audience.
Production quality has grown crisp
column2: polished and cheap. Kids can hear more music

column1: Distribution with the internet and the matured market puts CDs in Wyoming and Andorra.
Les Savy Fav's approach rouses the early days of punk-- the late 70's and 80's. Fans still claim
the Clash couldn't make a great record
column2: which seems preposterous these days. But those fans

column1: saw the Clash live. Certainly Minor Threat's live shows punched the gut harder than their 7""s.
Seeing a band live was essential. Back then
column2: attendance and word of mouth mattered more. Don't

column1: take this as a discount of the modern scene. What I'm trying to get at is that Les Savy Fav
make great records
column2: which are not necessarily meant to out-do their live show

column1: and supplement the band's physical presence instead. So just listen.
The Cat and the Cobra progresses further than Les Savy Fav's debut
richer mix
column3: and a slightly more confrontational sound. The once-

column1: subtle Brainiac elements have blossomed into obvious touchstones. The Frankenstein bass and
sparking guitar of ""We've Got Boxes"" brings to mind Hissing Prigs in Static Couture.
Warbling vocal effects and unnatural bass undulations under ""Wake Up!"" also recall Dayton's
late innovators. ""The Orchard"" opens with resigned
column2: sighing vocals and chiming melodic picks

column1: that eventually add hammers and dynamite to Smart Went Crazy's style of art-pop. Elsewhere
the attitude and duel guitar punji stabs continue the spirit of the Pixies.
But clearly the focus of Les Savy Fav is the brilliantly demented Tim Harrington. He spits
the most contrived sentiments with such conviction that it immediately becomes new gospel.
On ""Who Rocks the Party
column2: cries of ""Who rocks the party like we rock the body body!"" lead into

column1: declarations of
column2: ""They can let loose the dogs on us/ Because the dogs like us more than the

column1: dogs like them!"" It may read stupid
column2: but how often have you shouted ""I am un chein andolusian!""

column1: along with Black Francis on ""Debaser?""  Meanwhile
column2: drums throb underneath. No fills. No high

column1: hats. Guitars screech. It's primal and reviving.
Let's face it
punk fresh. This is about a mission. This isn't about songs or being catchy. But
somehow it is. Les Savy Fav belong on Dischord at the turn of the last decade
luck gave them to us now

column2: orchestral death balladry of ""Without You"" (a cover)

This is a recording of great songs and it deserves a good rating

column1: Homespun is a strange one. These are the demos of the entire Apple Venus Vol. 1
record
column2: sequenced in the same order. This means that those who buy this record after knowing

column1: and loving Apple Venus will have to sit through essentially the same album again
those who don't own Apple Venus would probably be better off with the real deal. So
what's the thinking here
column2: exactly? I can see the Beatles releasing those Anthology tapes

column1: after all those years
column3: but why would XTC follow up a record with another

column1: record containing demos of the same tunes?
The decision to release these tapes seems even stranger when you consider that most of these
demos don't differ much from their studio-recorded counterparts. When you hear the word ""demo""
associated with Homespun
column2: don't go in expecting it to sound like it was recorded in

column1: Robert Pollard's garage or anything.  Frontman Andy Partridge and cohort Colin Moulding have
what sound like extremely sophisticated setups in their home studios
record would put many professional recordings to shame.  And they don't sound like they were
shotgunning Budweisers between takes
So
column2: the differences are in the details
column3: as on the orchestral backing of tunes like ""River of

column1: Orchids"" and ""Easter Theater
column2: where Partridge triggers the string parts (with identical

column1: arrangements to the final versions) with a sampler. It's a convincing replication of a chamber
orchestra
column3: but it obviously doesn't sound as rich and full as the

column1: final Apple Venus take. More valuable are the skeletal versions of songs like ""I'd Like
That"" and ""Harvest Festival"" (both of which contain a brief selection from an earlier
dirtier take) that sound almost like proper demos. These particular tracks chip away at the
glossy veneer of the final album recordings
column2: revealing a melodic sense solid to the core.

column1: For XTC fanatics
column2: who this collection is surely geared toward

column1: detailed liner notes that give an entertaining overview of the genesis of every piece. But

column2: this record stands as a further testament to a great songwriter. Partridge has spoken

Brian Wilson.  Judging from his life's work

Sometimes an artist just nails an album title; this accomplishment cannot be underrated. When

column1: so many bands tack on throwaway lines
column3: the label's pick for the first single

column1: random acquisitions that require extended narratives that tax even Serena Altschul's
near-beatific tolerance for rock and roll bullshit
column2: one simply has to give credit when someone does

column1: it right. Naming an instrumental album with artistic conviction requires no small degree of
insight and introspection; an artist must stand far enough from the work to see it clearly.
Ui's The Iron Apple EP simply could not stand under any other banner.
The Iron Apple
column2: like Burgess' ""A Clockwork Orange"" and Burroughs' ""The Soft Machine

column1: struggles with lines between organic and inhuman. This is Ui at their most experimental and
tweaked. Ui's 1995 debut
column3: used the irresistible force of twin Fender Bass

column1: guitars to twine grooves around a solid
year's Lifelike went farther into New York post-rock
leanings served as the thinnest of lifelines while the music itself rocketed start- and- stop
into the oddest time signatures and bizarre sonic hybrids.  The album was weird
so-- all of its exhilarating strangeness smacked of calculation-- which alienated many and
enthralled others.
I sincerely hope that The Iron Apple EP is stalking out the future trajectories of Ui's
strange wanderings. The five-track EP progresses from the very Lifelike-sounding
opening track
column2: ""Mrs. Lady Lady"" into cooler and cooler dimensions of abstraction. The title

column1: tracks is the sound of music being pumped full of strange inert gasses: one notices the
signature grooves fail to synch up
column2: and the spaces between instruments and notes becomes

column1: unbridgeable. The tendency is always from groove to mechanism
column2: from the camaraderie of a trio

column1: of humans jamming with fluidity to musical miscommunication and alienation-- which is not to
suggest musical ineptitude but rather an ear for sounds in insolation.  The third track
Lady
column2: is undergirded by squawks of fuzz noise as the guitars proceed tenuously into the

column1: disorder and attempt to construct precarious grooves which never seem to hold together.
Something else always emerges.
""Golden Pietro"" makes nods to the style of futurism explored by Trans Am on Futureworld
with sparse drum machines and looming synths. A Fender jazz bass plucks desperately at odd
intervals; frightening whines of buzzsaw sounds starting cutting up the background. The
buzzsaws become talk box guitar for the last few seconds of the track. The effect is unnerving.
""Run Pietro"" is the least coherent track on the disc and somehow the best and most emblematic.
The noisy analog effects are held in perfect sway with limpid acoustic guitar lines. That Ui
groove is there but you have to stand far back to see it
column2: to hear it unfolding over a greater

column1: sense of time. In some sense
column2: they've lost the ass-swaggering bass guitar love that made

column1: Sidelong such a great album to party to
column2: but The Iron Apple puts Ui's closet

column1: funk algebraics to such impressive use. This is why the title of the disc struck me as so
telling: there still resides a deep

Similarly

Gorky's can commendably serve country and folk flavors to doggedly indie- rock palates. No

My career counselor once advised me to seek disappointment. No doubt Mr. Thirp thought he was imparting in that vaguely oriental
column2: gnomic nugget some great wisdom that would see me through my turbulent adolescence and ready me for the tangles and thickets of adulthood. Well
column4: and I'm ready to testify that I was not prepared.

column1: Now I'm ready to confess that I'm not the most dyed- in- the- wool Pet Shop Boys fan
column4: sly verbal parries and a fine
column5: stompin' four- to- the- floor amyl groove. But I'm so upset
column6: it's the utmost I can do to stifle my tears
column7: lest I short out my laptop. Nightlife
column8: the follow-up to the Boys'sizzling fusion of Latin rhythms
column9: deep house and jaded insouciance
column10: Bilingual
column11: is a mush of half- arsed trance
column12: lyrics worthy of a late- middle- aged romance authoress and misguided R&B.; But it's Neil Tennant's wanton disregard for his own talents that's the real shame here.

column1: Now
column2: I believed Tennant wholeheartedly when he sang ""Do I Have To?"" and ""I Would Normally Do This Kind of Thing."" I swooned when he crooned the chestnutty ""Always On My Mind."" He were almost the Noel Coward of dance pop-- the Cole Porter of Mies van der Rohe- furnished house! But now he tries us with clunky would- be aphorisms and bon mots. Did he think we wouldn't gag on lines like
column3: ""Hear a song/ That's the bomb!/ If you don't get that mix/ It's gone '86!"" and ""When loneliness induces fear/ Like waves against a ramshackle pier""?

column1: Nightlife opens with the Rollo- produced and consequently extremely radio- friendly
column3: a cautionary tale about the dangers of paying for sex when Neil Tennant is waiting to give you a cuddle and sympathy for free. Of course
column4: one shouldn't expect a Pet Shop Boys album to open like a Jansky Noise/ VVM soundclash
column5: but the rococo blandness of ""For Your Own Good
column6: which relies heavily on samples from Rollo's Faithless project
column7: sets one up for the mightiest disappointment since the lonesome evening you discovered that you couldn't perform auto- fellatio.

column1: Much in the same
column2: erm... vein does Tennant work out his theological conundrums and his highest falsetto on ""Closer to Heaven."" The song isn't the rapturous disco paean to the profound beauty of the Trinity as one might have believed
column4: Tennant dwells on the fact that whomever he's smitten with is-- gasp!-- both an angel and a devil. Yeah
column5: only in a dance track could one hope to astound a captive audience with such insight. I just hope those shimmying to this effort are astoundingly bolloxed on a nine inch line of Special K snorted off some rank club urinal.

column1: Matters marginally improve with ""I Don't Know What You Want But I Can't Give It Anymore."" Here
column2: Tennant develops and extemporizes on the theme of material gain and its inability to satisfy the desires which prowl our base natures. Or else he reckoned that being Everything But the Girl for a day would be beezer fun. But unlike ETBG's Tracey Thorn
column3: Tennant doesn't have the dramatic vocal skill to make this song anything more than first- single- off- the- album radio fodder.

column1: Yeah
column2: Nightlife has tracks that you could play on the radio
column3: and then there are those that should be played only to those willing to be subjected to the utmost degradation and dehumanization. How else are we supposed to describe the computer- as- metaphor conceit of ""Happiness is an Option"" (as though emotions were selected in the preferences dialog box of the human mind) or the undying irritation induced by ""Vampires.""

column1: It doesn't pain me in the slightest not to delve into the swill that marks out the collaboration with Kylie Minogue (""In Denial"")-- suffice to say it's an ever- so- dramatic dialog between a daughter and her gay dad. But the rank slurry that is ""New York City Boy"" demands my attention (and your avoidance).
Superficially
column2: the track is a sort of coming home song and a reply to the Boys' version of the Village People's ""Go West."" But
column3: taking a second to examine ""New York City Boy"" (for that's all you'll need)
column4: you'll soon realize that it's actually just a blatant rip off of that song. The track boasts a chantably identical chorus in addition to the same massed choir belting out the song in the worst Andrew Lloyd Webber fashion. Tennant barely makes an appearance; I hope that his decision to cop out of vocal duties was prompted by his shame and putting his band's name to such goop.

column1: One moral I've drawn from this wretched record: don't have high expectations of pop stars. Despite their protestations
column2: they'll never fail to let you down. Despite myself
column3:
I'll seek solace in my beloved Gay Dad album.

Im Anfang war die Tät. In the beginning was the deed. This is the first line of Goethe's

column1: Faust and arguably the most famous words in the German language. The opening lines of the
Gospel of John
column2: ""In the beginning was the Word"" are inverted in a penstroke. The whole Christian

column1: tradition is turned on its head. We do not originate in the benediction of an incarnated word
but in the hazard of an unmediated act. That single line contains an entire manifesto of work
the rough beauty of human effort and human suffering. Can anything be quite as Protestant
quite as German as that?
If ever there was a band to whom the Protestant work ethic could be applied
Can. If there was music that discarded the timelessness of pop for the earthbound temporality of
experimentation
column2: it is Can music. The sound of Can is the sound of labor

column1: exertion. Other collective improvisers like the Mahavishnu Orchestra approach the idiom of the
mystical
column2: while Can seems geared for construction. They had mastered a true industrial sound

column1: before that term was squandered on the sound of sparse rhythm and dreary
Genesis P. Orange screaming: ""Discipline!"" ad nauseam.  Can is itself an industry. Indeed
industrial revolution. Their product strains description.
The double disc Box Music (1971-1977) also eludes language. If architecture is frozen
music
column2: then Can is liquid architecture. These five men build earthworks so impossibly elaborate

column1: that it cannot even survive the process of its own construction: when the workmen have disappeared
so has the building. Box Music outstrips the tight tapeloop experimentalism of classics
like Tago Mago and Future Days precisely because it is so heavy
Leibezeit's jackhammer drums
column2: the pig-iron slabs of Holger Czukay's bass

column1: sheet metal keyboards
column2: and the relentless industrial drill of Michael Karoli's guitars. The

column1: cumulative effect would be machine-like if the collective sound were not so violent and haphazard.
The music remains organic because it sweats and suffers; you can hear fatigue and elation
and struggle. Silence is weakness.
Box Music culls non-professional recordings-- mostly cassette-- from the group's most
experimental years
column2: the years when Japanese street poet Damo Suzuki handled the vocals

column1: the departure of their original lead singer
appears on a track from 1975). Suzuki's role on Box Music is somewhat limited
again
column2: Can's music was never driven by vocals. The sound is too intensely collective to allow

column1: space for a single voice
column2: almost tribal. The title of their earliest recordings captures it:

column1: Future Primitive. One can never tell whether it's the music of civilization coming or going.
It is always devouring itself.
The 14-minute ""Voo Doo Right"" from a 1975 show
column2: is tribal savagery at its zenith

column1: and keyboards into a huge bonfire

phase-shifted funk as Schmidt's keyboards surface. Karoli's guitar is lyrical and lysergic
the upper air in serpentine passes before devolving into mechanized crunch. There is a momentary

the Velvet Underground's locomotive signature ""Sister Ray"" in space. Suzuki's beat whispering is

When it comes to poetic justice
column2: Ryan Schreiber is second only to God. Ever wonder why it takes     him so long to get our discs to us to review? Because he's portioning out holy recompense for     each of our virtues and each of our transgressions. Every time he sends out that big list of     review discs to the Pitchfork writers he seems to say
column3: just like God: ""I have set life and death     before you this day. Choose life."" I have actually caught him on occasion wearing an oversized     white t-shirt with CHOOSE LIFE written in big letters
column4: to reinforce his message. I asked if he     had any fingerless fluorescent gloves to go along with it and he punched me in the stomach. I     asked him to ""help me up before you go-go"" and he kicked me in the back. I swear if it weren't     for all the money and the floozies
column5: I'd have a good mind to quit this job.

column1: Ah
column2: poetic justice! Not the casual ass-whooping-- those are just par for the course. Rather the     irrevocable fact that I am inevitably compensated for my pretensions with every piece of     avant-jazz
column3: experimental noise or Kranky-style cerebral post-rock that traffics through the     front offices at One Pitchfork Way. Every shipment of discs I get seem to scream: deconstruct     this
column5: I find myself on the business end of an OED and a dog-eared copy of     Adorno
column6: trying to come up with two dozen different ways of saying the word ""groove"" without     being implicated in a bourgeois aesthetic ideology. Goddamnit
column7: how many discs can I describe as ""Kafkaesque"" without eventually losing every last shred of credibility? I don't even know what rock music sounds like anymore.

column1: What's in the mail today? A McArthur fellow fronting reinterpretations of the free jazz work of an obscure Jamaican alto player. See what I mean?
The contributions of Joe Harriott (1928-1973) to the free-improv movement have largely gone unnoticed. Branded a follower of the celebrated free jazz pioneer
column3: Harriott     didn't live long enough-- nor famously enough-- to have the world take pause at his radical     innovations in modal jazz. Students now suggest that the London-based Harriott and the American     Ornette developed their compositional and improvisational technique in near-total isolation     from one another
column4: advocating a strong review of Harriott's ideas in light of his removal from the American free jazz scene of the 1960's.

column1: Like John Zorn's hyperkinetic 1989 Spy vs. Spy
column2: a furious reinterpretation of Ornette     Coleman's work as composer
column3: Ken Vandermark's Joe Harriott Project isn't offering a tribute
column4: but     a retelling. Harriott's arrangements are transformed into Vandermark's spacious and disconnected     lines. The signature piano of Harriott's work is absent
column5: and the alto is augmented by clarinet and trombone duels intertwined in the rhythm. The album exudes a beatnik vibe of radical ease.

column1: Vandermark's staccato sax lines suggest a Joe Harriott refracted through the work of another short-lived horn player
column2: the immortal Eric Dolphy. The sparse angular attack is always executed     with meticulous control
column3: free from any trace of the excess or self-indulgence that seems to mar     other contemporary exercises in collective improvisation. Even the fragmented ""Shadows"" remains     intensely lyrical
column4: while the defiantly looping ""Straight Lines"" is reminiscent of the near-perfect     Oliver Nelson album
column6: in muted uprising and subdued discord. Jeb Bishop's quiet trombone solo on the title track is one of the album's simple highlights. The entirety of Straight Lines revels in the glory of revision: the giddy thrill of hearing for the first time what the world was formerly deaf to.

column1: As for me
column2: I can't complain. I thrive on precisely this kind of music
column3: this marriage of melody     and resistance. Sure
column4: it sounds like a boulder slipping down from the top of a great hill in     hell
column5: but for a sound this strong
column6:
I'm willing to go back down to the bottom again.

Any record being released with a moderate amount of hype will almost

have been irreparably damaged by years of exposure to loads and loads
of shitty music.
2. Slimy publicist types that aren't afraid to trade a little fellatio
for a winning review.
3. The protecting hand of Yahweh.
This goes a long way toward explaining the large majority of popular culture.
But every once in a while

column1: reviewer
column2: deservedly earning absurdly high marks with nary a scratch.  Such is

on Both Sides.
But

column1: starters
column2: nobody serviced me to write this.  Not since the emergence of A Tribe

has hip-hop seen an MC as intelligent
smooth as Mos Def.

coming.  If you didn't

column3: and repent.  With artists like this finally

Mos Def.  The man does it all-- addressing serious socio-political issues while

True

During my adolescence
column2: I was an outsider. I was separate from my fellows not because of some

So it wasn't long before I wanted a pair of winkle-pickers instead of the sturdy Hush Puppies

am an outsider

maybe that's not his plan. Perhaps he's just more comfortable being an insider.

If there's anything more terrifying in pop culture than the supergroup

band classics à la the Make Up.

the freedom to push artistic forms through concepts. And techno head
amongst that number. For in Stabiles he has constructed a high art album of sparse yet
funky beats and subdued ambiance that should secure maximum rotation in Manhattan art dealers'

No

column1: inspiration. Calder is praised for his often immense metal sculptures that
metallic
column2: have branches and arms that spin and weave within each other when the wind blows.

column1: In short
column2: Calder sculpted paradoxical mobiles-- objects that look as though they weigh tons

column1: but when a slight breeze blows
column2: the mass evaporates and the sculpture becomes weightless

column1: airy
It's not a bad model for a techno artist to employ
column2: given that the genre excels in the harsh

column1: and heavy. If you're at all familiar with the releases from Berlin's Chain Reaction label
imagine those distinctive rhythms without the softened white noise and hiss that sometimes
detract from the accessibility and the elegance of the imprint.
For Stabiles
column2: Stewart Walker set up discreet loops of rhythm and let them spin on top

column1: and through each other. Occasionally
column3: he'll add a tiny cricket- like

column1: sound to throw the beat out of whack. At the conclusion of ""Missing Winter
an ambient section that would not be out of place on one of those majestic tape- loop
collaborations between Robert Fripp and Brian Eno.  Walker occasionally even hints at a
melody and lures us in even further. ""Sunclipse
combines all these tricks and is as graceful as it is avant garde.
It's pretty astoundingly given the strict parameters Walker gave himself
length of the disc (just two seconds shy of an hour)
repetitive. There's always a new combination of loops to follow their meandering. If you've
never seen a Calder sculpture
column2: take it from me-- Walker's more than met his goal; he's risen

column1: to the challenge with precision
column4: so you can't dance to it.  On the

column1: other hand
column2: Stabiles is an album every bit as beautiful as Calder's works and it costs

Now

aren't you tickled that Deep Purple didn't get there first?

The Long Review:
Judd handed me a purple children's book and said
column2: ""Check this out."" The hardback felt about the size of     a gatefold double vinyl album. In bold letters
column3: the cover proclaimed The Worst Band in the Universe! Immediately we opened the book in an attempt to discern which band the author
column5: had in mind     while writing the picture book. Toto and Gomez came to mind. Yet upon finishing the first page
column6: I muttered
column7: ""Man
column8: this book is about The Dismemberment Plan.""

column1: As Pitchfork readers know
column2: I like to come up with wild and crazy scenarios for record reviews.  The songs     from the Plan's latest record
column4: had been making love to my brain for over a year
column5: and I wanted my review to perfectly capture my faith and prophecy for the album. Ironically
column6: ""the worst band in the universe"" captured my sentiments perfectly. The book begins:

column1: On Planett Blipp
column4:
The world was ruled by music-- but tradition called the tune.
The Ancient Songs of ages past were all that could be heard
column5: And no one was allowed to change a single note or word.

column1: To write a new tune was heresy
column3:
And anyone who improvised was scowled upon and cursed.
For years untold the temple walls had rung to songs of yore--
Until the day a brave young groob named Sprocc rewrote the score.

column1: He took his trusty Spligtwanger
column3: He cranked the volume up to ten and played a Brand New Song.

column1: The elders banish Sprocc from his planet
column2: leaving him to wander the galaxy with his ragtag band. They     stumble upon a contest for ""the worst band in the universe
column3: and naturally win. As it's a children's     book
column4: Sprocc and his jamming outfit return home and establish a new order of song. Lessons are learned.     Hands are held. Cue sunset
column6: little babies.

column1: The Dismemberment Plan spit in the face of modern music. Perhaps their coup is more analogous to an unexpected sloppy french kiss
column2: in terms of saliva imagery. But Emergency & I heralds a new era in rock and roll. Nothing else you own sounds like this record
column3: yet everything you own echoes throughout.     The Dismemberment Plan's chromosomes carry the superior DNA of rock's genealogy through a natural sexual     affair with music
column4: not the cold process of cloning. The perfect nucleotides of the Pixies
column6: Fugazi
column7: and Prince spindle in beautiful double-helixes throughout these 12 tracks. Specific     moments recall Gang of Four (""8\xBD Minutes"") or Radiohead (""The Jitters"")
column8: but this melange is wholly     unique-- boiled down for synapse-popping flavor. Certainly some will scratch their heads
column9: but innovation is never unanimously understood.

column1: Keyboards are enjoying a recent renaissance in rock. I believe even Snapcase tour with a Korg. But while pop groups are content to sprinkle Moog hooks or create false string sections with their Yamahas
column2: The     Dismemberment Plan squeeze alien funk and digital soul from their ebony and ivory. Deep
column3: gurgling squirts     carry ""A Life of Possibilities"" in place of bass. Mainframe bleeps add android soul to ""Memory Machine"".     An overly synthesized score shifts behind ""Spider in the Snow""
column5: yet inevitably sounding even more sincere. But the beautiful
column6: yearning hum that hangs over     ""The City"" like purple-orange sky pollution emotes more than a bruised diva-- it simultaneously aches     and uplifts. The tumbling drums pleasantly propel like public transit. Frustrated guitars chime like     flashes of streetlights in passing puddles. The alienation and excitement
column7: the desolate and the bustling--     the title simply envelopes the themes. By the time Travis Morrison begins crying
column8: ""All... I... ever...     say... now... is... good... bye
column9: angels are spooning out your stomach with ladles and visions of your distant past are punching you in the face.

column1: The closing track
column3: grooves into brilliance. Bringing to mind Talking Heads' Remain in Light
column4: the layers lock in bliss.  Funky drums
column6: synthetic slides
column7: and joyous keyboard     hooks circle tightly like bareback thoroughbreds in Siena's Palio. This track
column8: along with the explosive     ""I Love a Magician"" and ""Girl O'Clock""
column9: hint at new futures. Hometown fans have staged elaborate costumed     breakdancing during Dismemberment Plan sets
column10: and these songs are the hormonal fuel. The Plan rule during     schizophrenic dance-punk explosions
column11: somehow finding middle ground between Brainiac and Prince. As a     testament to the Plan's power
column12: these songs have turned D.C.'s traditionally head-bobbing concert crowds into cathartic bacchanals. Can I get an ""Amen?""

column1: Around the time Kurt Cobain muttered ""I think I'm dumb
column4: and extended metaphor have ruled rock lyrics since. Perhaps more importantly than their music
column5: the Plan     offer a return to intelligent
column6: ripe
column7: narrative songwriting. An air of despair hangs over the album
column8: spiked     with humor and passion. A definite debt is owned to hip-hop and soul
column9: but don't think that Morrison simply     barks a sequence of rhyming phrases. He ponderously spits on ""Back and Forth"": ""And faces slide by in     glowing shadows like snowbound ghosts that go up and down in epileptic shivers and negative radioactive     shivers in a landscape of endless dull glitter and a taste in my mouth so sweet
column10: yet so bitter-- and we     exhaust ourselves trying to get there."" Philosophy is backed up with primitive yelps like
column11: ""Put your hands     in the air
column13: death and humdrum lives are examined with alacrity. I     guarantee you that if you're a twentysomething
column15: ""Spider in the Snow"" and ""Gyroscope""     will knock you back into a couch and force a slight ""fuck"" from between your lips. At the very least
column16: you'll hum along for the rest of your 20s.

column1: I could spend pages examining this record. Everything down to the art is stunningly unique and perfectly appropriate. Even standard guitar pop numbers like ""What Do You Want Me to Say"" hit like a high-strung Weezer. A full range of emotions-- orgasm
column6: rage-- ooze from     The Dismemberment Plan. Paradox is woven throughout-- the alien and the nostalgic
column7: the nascent and the     classic. It's unfortunate that the term ""new wave"" is still linked to the early 80s. Bands like Jets to     Brazil are unimaginatively trying to revive that new wave sound.  But The Dismemberment Plan is truly
column8: unequivocally
column9: the new new wave. Emergency & I
column10: fittingly
column11: was delayed until the close     of the century. (Hey
column13:
does ""Boston Red Sox"" ring any bells?) Let's get this era over with. Please form a line behind the fellows in the sweaty button-down shirts.

column1: But every now and then

column3: like the fluttering sample on ""To Be Free Again
column4: the slide-guitar coda of ""Find The Hour
column5: or the gently crackling static in the background of ""Tar The Roofs."" And there are at least two songs
column6: ""Shifty Lies"" and ""Shoveling Sons

For his cover of Eddie Floyd's 1969 single ""Consider Me
Trees frontman Mark Lanegan eschews the original song's doo-wop background
singers and muffles the plush horn section that bears its Stax/Volt pedigree.
He leans his gravelly groan on the chorus' lead in (""You're gonna need a man/
A man who'll understand"")
column2: lending urgency and a smoky mystery to this

column1: otherwise fairly pedestrian refrain.  Why does the woman in this song need
so much understanding?  Why is her need so dire?  What has she done to cause
the abandonment of her friends?  There's a creeping darkness in Lanegan's
voice here-- something not apparent in the jumpy R&B; of the original.  It's
the realization of a transgression unimaginable at the time of the track's
original release.  By the time Lanegan gets around to crooning the song's
plaintive chorus
column2: we're left wondering if his ostracized subject really has

column1: any choice but to accept his offer.
By slightly tweaking its connotation
column2: Lanegan transports the song into a

column1: context of his own making.  It's this context
on I'll Take Care of You
column2: that allows the album's unique success.

column1: Compared to standard cover songs
column2: where there's almost always an obvious

column1: disconnect between the song and the band
own.  See
column2: this is a collection of songs that are of the same origin and

column1: landscape as Lanegan's previous works-- a landscape recognizable as the
stark
column2: tortured midnight soul of his previous three solo affairs.  And

column1: while molding classics-- like O.V. Wright's gospel testimony ""On Jesus'
Program"" or the traditional ""Little Sadie""-- into this landscape may not
seem like a stretch
column2: placing them seamlessly alongside the Gun Club's

column1: ""Carry Home"" and the Leaving Trains' ""Creeping Coastline of Lights""
definitely is.
Superficially
column2: I'll Take Care of You isn't much of an achievement

column1: for Lanegan.  After all
column2: he didn't write any of these songs

column1: explore much new sonic territory.  It's the type of album artists generally
release to fulfill a contract or take a breather.  But examined closely
it's much more than that.  Because in this collection
tug on the timeless threads that hold the patchwork of American music together.

And that's certainly something to consider.
