I read somewhere
column2: and tend to believe as true
column3: that there exists in music     criticism a two- tier model through which all artists are judged.  The first     pool of artists
column4: either newcomers rewarded for the ingenuity inherent in     merely possessing a new voice on the scene-- or elders of whom we've learned     to expect little more-- tend to be judged on the merits of their output's     strongest songs alone.  A newcomer finding success under the lower tier
column5: one     who establishes the kind of expectations that ride the back of credibility
column6: may find him or herself flung into the second pool
column7: where output is judged     solely on its worst moments.  Simply put
column8: reviewers
column9: and fans in general
column10: apply the bias of our expectations on artists.  Is this fair?  Perhaps not
column11: but considering the artist is asking us to buy a second
column14: I suppose we deserve a good old- fashioned reason why.

column1: Ben Harper once resided among the neophytes of the first pool. An eclectic writer and musician
column2: Harper was blessed with many crowns upon the release of     his debut
column3: the dour Welcome to the Cruel World. On the album's best tracks
column4: he seemed rock's social conscience and the heir apparent to the fusion     of soul
column5: funk and rock championed by the likes of Jimi Hendrix and Bob Marley.     We easily ignored the album's less successful moments
column6: and rightfully so. Fight for Your Mind followed and found Harper expanding his already substantial range (the album's two best songs
column7: ""Ground On Down"" and ""Burn     One Down"" are among the best funk and reggae this decade has produced) and     building on the foundation of his first release.  However
column8: the album retained     some of the first's miscues
column9: in particular
column10: the slow- plodding ballads that seem to be a motif for the young Californian.

column1: Will to Live was
column5: more     troublesome. Harper seemed to hone his vision
column6: and in doing so mitigated some     of the previous albums' lows.  He turned towards a more straight- forward rock     sound
column7: mirroring Lenny Kravitz's shift towards center after Let Love Rule. While this transformation helped Harper produce perhaps his most consistent work to date
column8: it also rendered the album a bit bland.  Harper's eclectic vision     had all but disappeared
column9: and the album enjoyed few great revelations. That the album disappointed was perhaps the first sign that Harper had graduated into the second tier of artists-- the ones who carry our expectations as their burden.

column1: If so
column2: then Burn to Shine may be an equally telling sign that he's not quite ready. Harper continues the trends formed on Will to Live
column3: moving     further toward simple classic rock songs and away from the hints of emotional     complexity that brought him his best achievements.  Though the ragtime jaunt     ""Suzie Blue"" is a feign (and an unwelcome one at that)
column4: Harper plays a plainer     hand here.  The album's first three tracks are exasperatingly mediocre by his     standards
column5: and although his Robert Plant imitation on ""The Woman in You"" saves     the song
column6: the repetition of its chorus ad nauseam begins a trend that often     isn't graced with similar rescue throughout the remainder of the album.  ""Less
column7: on the other hand
column8: is a stab at heavy metal
column9: which is all the further I choose to comment on it.

column1: But once again
column2: Ben Harper manages to string together moments of brilliance.     The trio formed by the warm- hearted raga ""Steal My Kisses
column4: and the soulful ""Show Me a Little Shame
column5: are the strength of the album
column6: and more or less carry the listener through its less- than- spectacular     remainder.  For better or worse
column7: these finer moments set a higher standard for     Harper.  And this being the guy's fourth album
column8: we really need more than a few     great songs to make it worth the cash.  Harper is an electric performer and his     risky but blistering live cover of Hendrix's ""Voodoo Chile"" hints at his rightful     place among today's rock musicians.  Unfortunately
column9:
Burn to Shine fails to put him there.

Lee Hazlewood

column2: Hazlewood was an enigmatic contemporary of Phil

column1: Cheesy? God

column1: Still
column3: with Hazlewood's stellar production and subtle

column1: understated arrangements (mostly just bass and guitar)
something greater. An artifact
this any more
column2: all rich and full of romantic atmosphere. But there's something

column2: a simplicity that yields a kind of grandeur.

column1: The melodies (particularly on such weepers as ""If It's Monday Morning"" and ""I'll
Live Yesterdays"") show that Hazlewood fully understood the power of the 1-5

ah yes... Lee got it right.

The neighborhood record store offers a necessary crutch-- a place to run with terminally unlistenable discs
which one can trade in for something more worthy of aural ingestion.  But what about all the used discs that
you know in the bottom of your heart will never be sold?  The bottomless $1.99 bins would surely be an
intimidating reminder of cash spent lost to pimply-faced adolescents peddling Phatfunk discs.  What to do
with these materially valueless artifacts?
If you're Amsterdam record shop owner Elizabeth Esselink
and wage war with the Hitmeister.  As Solex
column2: Esselink assembles junk-pop symphonies from unwanted discs and

column1: lays distinctive Casio lines and sultry stream-of-consciousness storylines on top.  But this is no dead-end
process
column2: as one might expect-- Pick Up is the second long-player of Esselink's distinctively bouncy

column1: nonsensical songwriting
column2: and takes several steps forward from her intriguing debut

column1: Hitmeister.
Esselink's accomplished sampler orchestrations are more self-assured this time around.  The title track opens
with a muted trumpet and a rapidly accelerating beat before blossoming into a sing-songy assemblage of
portentous horn punctuations and guitar strummage.  She displays a chaotic command of rhythm in propelling
her pieces forward-- every musical snatch follows its own platonic beat but somehow results in an illogically
swinging lilt.  By the end of ""Randy Costanza
column3: Esselink has managed to cram two repeating string

column1: motifs alongside a two-looped guitar chord structure
column2: and throw a polyrhythmic shuffle in for good measure.

column1: The intrinsic tempos of each vie against the rest for cadenced domination
column2: but the result is harmonious flow.

column1: It shouldn't work
Esselink's vocals lend cohesion to the songs
column2: and her lyrics give you something else to wrap your head around

column1: when following the musical free-association becomes too much.  With song titles like ""That's What You Get with
People like That on Cruises like These...""
assured that her lyrical muse is as eccentric and far-reaching as her musical one.
Pick Up is hearty pop fun for the detritus age. Esselink's productions are so characteristic
that it's difficult not to feel bogged down by the musical cut-and-paste formulae.  And though she enlisted
some friends to flesh out assorted tracks with original instrumental contributions
Nevertheless
column2: Pick Up is a strong developmental achievement in the right direction for Solex

column1:
stand as inspiration for used record store owners the world over.

Exciting times
column2: these! So what if the Messiah didn't turn up on the Eve of the New Millennium?

column1: What do we need some sandled beardy-weirdy for
column2: anyway?  Less than two full months into 2000

column1: we got Primal Scream's Molotov incendiary device
emaciated
column2: once-revolutionary specters of the Stooges and the MC5

column1: all over them. Brill!
The rollover of the century also saw avant-jazz taking on electronica and offering us the hope
that smooth jazz wasn't the end of the road for that great tradition.  Compare Autechre's
LP5 with Elliot Sharpe's Errata and you'll be gobsmacked by the similarities and
the friendly rivalries.  Shit
column2: what if Jelly Roll Morton and King Oliver had had PowerBooks and

column1: CuBase rather than rusty trombones and bordello pianos?  What freaky shit we'd be listening
to now! What if John Coltrane...? Or Ornette Coleman...?
The Cinematic Orchestra (aka J. Swinscoe) is coming from the other angle.  He's a veteran
electronica producer taking on jazz.  And unlike Sharp's ripping up of conventions
hung up on admiration. Motion is nothing less than a beat-driven tribute to Miles Davis'
collaborations with third stream arranger/composer Gil Evans.  Those 50's records (<i>Sketches
of Spain
column4: for example) threw away the hard-bop

column1: rulebook and attempted to find a third path between the irreverence of jazz and the academics
of the classical tradition.  Davis had already expressed that interest when his nonet recorded
The Birth of the Cool
column2: but the idea was fully realized on his recordings with Gil

column1: Evans.
Swinscoe obviously adores the glowing discords and the curious harmonies of ""Saeta"" (from
Sketches of Spain) and he's built Motion around them. Rather than using a
sampler to do all the work
column2: he's pulled together a small band and let his drum machine

column1: contribute the beats.
The opening track
column3: incorporates a sample of Nina Simone's heart-wrenching

column1: rendition of ""Strange Fruit"" and builds the close brass harmonies to a forceful climax.
""Diabolus"" takes a different approach to the same end and closes with an almost ambient
coda.  However
column2: Motion is ironically rigid. The hip-hop beats aren't sufficient to

column1: overcome Swinscoe's reverence for the tradition he cops from.  Too often the flow is ponderous
and self-conscious.
If Swinscoe had allowed his musicians the freedom of a true blowin'
session
column2: Motion could have been a signal moment in the much-needed dialog between the

column1: electronic and jazz avant-gardes.  Instead
column2: the album simply restates the obvious

column1: beautifully.  The revolution will not be held in a trendy coffee bar and Jesus won't return
until he's sure that there's some kick-ass music down here to soundtrack his second coming
and the destruction of all those whining bastards who've been bothering his poor

father for centuries.

So I was sweeping the kitchen floor this afternoon and decided that I would

the sound grew.  Soon it filled the apartment-- a spacious
crescendo... blaring louder and louder.  Sound reverberated off the
hardwood floors and high ceilings
thundering bass shook the building's foundation
drumbeat and crashing cymbal
column2: the roof lifted and fell.  90-mph streamline

column1: winds ripped through the window
column2: pushing me against the wall and crushing

column1: me under the weight of the refrigerator.  And finally
climax

Record of Small Histories is comprised of seven mostly instrumental tracks

column2: layering more instruments and building complex walls

actual pre-written melodies which lend some much needed direction and structure

column1: ""Lull
column3: and ""Tourist"" make it worth the Eeyore-ish mood it puts me in.

flute.  The divas spit and turn on each other.  The band runs for their
lives.
Channel 04:  ""The Art of Noose"" Dudley realizes she can never return to
the days of ""Legs.""  Morley and Horn stumble on a magic lamp
mid- tempo jam is tarnished when the genie turns out to be Kenny G.
Channel 05:  ""Para-NO!-Mia"" A mild rainstorm traps the group in the lobby
of a Mexican restaurant.  The divas return and lurk in a booth across
the room.  John Hurt woos a starstruck flamenco guitarist with his
silken
column2: bass- boosted voice.  Nobody notices when they slip away for

column1: their own wacky antics.
Channel 06:  ""Tart
column3: Boys"" Morley and Horn find their night out at a

column1: local Karaoke bar foiled when a jealous Dudley switches all the Madonna
records with sped- up polkas. (Repeat)
Channel 07:  ""Backbeatback Off (Part 1)"" The group does to Debussy what
Enigma did to Gregorian chant.  An uproar does not follow.  Rakim is
introduced as the only MC in the universe willing to rhyme ""ordinaire""
with ""Baudelaire"" while John Hurt talks huskily about perfume.
Channel 08: ""Backbeatback Off (Part 2)"" Unbelievably
Rakim suffers a stroke which leaves him able only to repeat the words
""Somethin' y'all would compare to Baudelaire"" repeatedly.  Dudley and
Horn attempt to cover for him
breakdancing. Morley goes off in search of a curry.
Channels 09-12: Paid programming.
Channel 13:  Dudley and Morley blur the line between ambient and a
near- fatal Zoloft overdose.  Horn is transported to another dimension
where he hides in a closet from the evil Anti- Horn.  The two come face

to face and disintegrate in a completely unspectacular fashion.

We're all so much older now and everything has changed. For example

column1: voted for Reagan in a mock school election in 1980-- the same year Echo
and the Bunnymen released their debut album
turned out
column2: I wasn't listening to Echo back then; my first exposure came

column1: via the beautiful single ""Bring on the Dancing Horses
during a key moment in the John Hughes film ""Pretty in Pink.""
I finally figured out that the reason John Hughes' shit hit so close to
home is that I was the exact age of the main characters in just about
every one of his 80's movies. I was just about to turn 16 when ""Sixteen
Candles"" went to theaters
column2: and by the time ""The Breakfast Club"" hit the

column1: big screen I already had three miserable years of high school under my
belt. So rather than being the time of my childhood
I became a man. Legally
In any case
column2: it wasn't until I entered adulthood and cast my first real

column1: non-mock vote in a presidential election (Dukakis and Bensten in '88!)
that I became intimately familiar with an Echo and the Bunnymen album.
My roommate Eric
column2: who covered our dorm room with Bauhaus and Depeche Mode

column1: posters to balance out my Pink Floyd laziness
self-titled record.  It came to be their last true album before they
broke up. It had a big college radio hit called ""Lips Like Sugar"" that
Eric liked to put on when we had parties. The sound of it still makes me
feel drunk and awkward.
Of course
column2: that album couldn't compare to their ""greatest hits"" compilation

column1: Songs to Learn and Sing
column2: which is still all the Echo anyone really

column1: needs
column2: and which also happens to be the first vinyl record I bought after

column1: getting a turntable again in 1996 (the year I voted for Ralph Nader). Now

column2: I'm almost certainly not going to vote at all

column1: spend some time listening to the new Echo and the Bunnymen album. I never
would have guessed it
Fittingly
column2: Ian McCulloch and friends have mellowed considerably on <i>What

column1: are You Going to Do with Your Life? The over-the-top
of yore have been replaced with an album of introspective
appropriate for these aging geezers. The title track nicely illustrates
this stripped-down approach
column2: with gentle guitar strums and some light

column1: brushwork on the drums providing the only backing for McCulloch's rich
resonant voice. He sounds more like Bono here than I remember
quality of his singing is perfect-- a weary voice transmitting from some
abandoned studio of yesteryear.
The strings on tunes like ""Rust"" and ""Fools Like Us"" remind us that Echo
were always one of the more classic rock-oriented of the new wave bands
and there's something vaguely comforting and cute about their overzealous
reach. More startling are the scattered horn accents
trumpet that gives ""When It Blows Over"" and ""Get in the Car"" their charms;
these songs sound like the AM radio-aping Jim O'Rourke's been into lately.
(Strange
column3: but it works well in this context.)  And when McCulloch

column1: brings it all back home with the melancholy piano tune
we realize why we liked Echo in the first place: they wrote
to write
column2: good songs. These old guys get my vote for most surprising

column1:
comeback of 1999.

column3: one producer excelled all others in seizing upon     a spanking brand new sound concept that many others have since tried     tirelessly to emulate. His name is not Sean Combs
column6: Steve Albini
column7: or even the RZA. You could argue that the honor     of defining a decade should go to Prince Paul
column8: but that skit thing just     pisses me off now. Sure
column9: it worked on Three Feet High and Rising but give it a rest
column10: people! My huge shout of hearty praise for shaping the musical landscape of this decade goes to Andrew Weatherall.

column1: It was Weatherall's remix of the lame
column2: floppy-fringed Primal Scream     dirge ""I'm Losing More Than I've Ever Had"" that broke dance culture out     from the warehouses and into the great wide cultural open. Weatherall's     remix of that track was so radically different from the source material     that the band retitled the track ""Loaded"" and the indie-led dance boom     burst forth on a generation raised on Sherbet Dib-Dabs
column3: a clipped ear for     being insolent
column4: and the highest quality tabs of ecstasy.

column1: In the fallout from ""Loaded
column2: record labels signed up any DJ for mixing     duties who knew one fader from another. Some have fallen by the wayside--     who here remembers Dean Thatcher?-- others went onto other forms of     greatness. But the fusion of indie rock and dance has never waned. The     Manic Street Preachers still cadge mixes from the Chemical Brothers
column3: as do the Charlatans UK. And the recent success of Super Furry Animals is directly attributable to Weatherall's pioneering.

column1: Don't think that Weatherall got the remixing gig by accident. He'd been assiduously garnering a following for his DJ sets at the seminal London Balearic and acid house club Shoom where he'd enthrall clubbers (luv'd up on pure MDMA) with his mix of DJ Pierre and the Clash. So after Bobby Gillespie and his troop discovered that this alchemist could rip up their sub-Byrdsian jangle into an anthem for the ecstasy generation
column2: Weatherall didn't have to worry about when the next pay check was coming in. Every record company wanted to cop a feel of the man's greatness.

column1: Weatherall conjured up classic after classic
column2: such as his mix of the     Grid's ""Floatation
column3: which remains one of the most sublime of Balearic     12""s
column4: and his dusted-up take on ""Abandon"" by This Petrol Emotion. His re-casing of James made that sad Mancunian band a vital listen and his spin on Bjork's ""One Day"" remains a highlight of her career.

column1: Weatherall became a major player in the Boys Own production camp and fanzine and went onto produce Primal Scream's mind-blowingly graceful Screamadelica album and its cheaper date sister
column2: One Dove's Morning White Dove. The latter could have surpassed Screamadelica in beauty had London Records not interfered and brought in pop-dance shite-hawker Stephen ""I Ruined New Order"" Hague to provide the beancounters with radio-friendly pop singles.

column1: Realizing he was becoming an overexposed remixer du jour
column2: Weatherall went underground. Would that Junior Vasquez and Peter Rauhoffer had similar integrity! Weatherall founded the Sabres of Paradise label and studio project and sought to mesh his predilection for urban fear with skunk-fuelled hip-hop and dub. Sabresonic can boast one of the finest remixes of all time-- David Holmes' acidic percussion workout of ""Smokebelch"" more than rebuffs any criticism that remixing is just a waste of time and marketing budget (which in many cases it is). Holmes became a part of the Sabres system and his breath- taking debut album This Film's Crap
column3: Let's Slash the Seats teams him up with Jagz Kooner and Gary Burns of the Sabres of Paradise.

column1: Weatherall wittily located his Sabresonic club in a disused railway arch under London Bridge station
column2: the area best known as the former prowling ground of Jack the Ripper. Weatherall would DJ his dubby hip-hop before guest DJs like Dr. Alex Paterson would knock clubbers out of their stoned groove with cyborg blasts such as Abfahrt's ""Come Into My Life"" (imagine the Band as a German hard techno act-- I gasp every time I hear this tune).

column1: Sabresonic (the album) was followed by Haunted Dancehall on which Weatherall pushed into prominence his love of Jamaican musical styles (reference ""Wilmot"" and ""Theme"" if you think I'm crazy). He layed down the blueprint for big beat (""Tow Truck"") in addition to producing skeletal techno similar to the ossified forms that Plastikman was putting out at the same time.
Before long
column2: Weatherall killed of the Sabres of Paradise
column4: and established the short-lived Emissions labels. But more lastingly
column5: he teamed up with former Emissions engineer Keith Tenniswood; the phoenix rose majestic once again as Two Lone Swordsman.

column1: The duo's debut album
column2: The Fifth Mission: Return to the Flightpath Estate
column4: ninja-trained to sneak up on     the listener and stick in the blade. The fact that the Two Lone Swordsmen     sustain our interest over a double CD is surely a testament to     Weatherall's complete mastery of atmosphere
column6: and above     all
column7: narrative. The Two Lone Swordsmen project works as (caution: overused critic's standby phrase approaching) a soundtrack to an unfilmed movie. The Fifth Mission is an existentially paranoid south London yakuza flick.

column1: Weatherall and Tenniswood released two album-length EPs in the aftershock of The Fifth Mission (Swimming Not Skimming and Stockwell Steppas) but both were limited releases and became woefully unavailable when the Emissions labels folded. Two Lone Swordsmen finally signed to Warp in the UK
column2: where the duo sit at the head     table with Aphex Twin
column5: and the Boards of Canada. In     the US
column6: Matador picked them up
column7: and over here the Two Lone Swordsmen find     themselves sharing a hugely diverse trough with the likes of Yo La Tengo
column8: Jon Spencer Blues Explosion
column9: and Cat Power.

column1: But Stay Down should be more than sufficient to deter you from buying a Guitar Wolf b-sides compilation
column2: or it may just get you out of     that bearably ceaseless Belle and Sebastian slump. It's less skunky than     its predecessors and more of an electroid groove. And if that's not enough     to sell you
column3: Matador's also tacked on an additional five tracks from the Warp-issued A Bag of Blue Sparks EP. These five tracks proudly showcase Weatherall's knack for distilling truly funky elements with an avantish twist. So ""Sticky"" and ""Gay Spunk"" could easily satisfy a Fatboy-wearied house party crowd while techno trainspotters can do backflips at having obtained the original version of ""Black Commandments"" (remixed by Jega as ""Unity Gain"" on his Spectrum LP).

column1: If Stay Down isn't the next big leap in the rolling evolution of techno
column2: it's at least a consolidation of Weatherall's long-lauded and     thoroughly well-deserved position as visionary producer and audio alchemist.      And if he's staying down now
column3:
he'll be up for air soon. I'm holding my breath on this one.

I was riding the Chicago L at 6:30 in the morning on a Sunday. The weather was cool with no
rain or humidity. A friend-- we'll call him ""Joe""-- had pointed me in the right direction
so I was now on the Blue Line ""to Forest Park"" at Damen.  I was headed to the loop so I could
switch over to the Orange Line for Midway.
The sun was up
column2: but was hidden behind the long row of buildings that stood there as if they

column1: were just people made of buildings. There were three other passengers in the car
probably writing his or her own record review. Mine was to be about the first solo recording
by Eleventh Dream Day/ Tortoise/ For Carnation guy Doug McCombs.  My first concern was whether
to call it a solo project or new band.  Was it really a solo effort?  He had quite a few people
playing with him.  But he wrote all the songs... I finally ended up deciding on ""solo effort
at about the same time that I arrived at the Monroe stop and exited the train.
At this point
column2: I needed to make my way through the city for a few blocks. I remembeOrange back to

column1: the first time I heard Tortoise. I bought their first album in the summer of 1994
Girls Against Boys' Cruise Yourself
Whip Smart. I didn't really get a chance to listen to the records until I was on an
airplane headed towards Ireland
column2: where I would spend the next year. Tortoise ended up making

column1: its way to my discman one night while I was busy trying to keep warm using three blankets and
a hot water bottle (the Irish didn't really believe in insulating their buildings). The music
filled the darkness of my room but
column3: left me with a feeling of moroseness and

column1: wonder. What struck me most was the bass-- it didn't play rhythms. It spoke. It walked around
the room
column3: then danced to the window. It was Doug McCombs. Well

column1: it was also Bundy K. Brown
With Brokeback
column2: McCombs is free to let his bass walk us through his version of the Chicago

column1: post-rock music scene. Releasing this album automatically relegated all his previous bands to
side- project status. It gave us a blueprint mapping essentially what Doug ""Puffy"" McCombs
brings to these other bands: the empty ambiance filled by plucked strings; the simple driving
melodies that wander from your speakers without settling anywhere in particular.
Hunger and my bag were weighing heavily as I climbed the stairway to the Jackson stop on the
Orange Line. I pulled out a bag of peanuts that I'd stashed during my flight in to Chicago.
Perfect. Eggs would have been better
column3: protein is protein. I got out my discman as

A friend of mine once remarked about the later music of John Coltrane and Miles Davis that the two musicians departed from the jazz tradition through completely opposite exits. Miles (for the moment we'll forget his unrelentingly mediocre '80s output) tended toward submergence of his voice. His '70s albums-- from the fiercely swaggering Jack Johnson to the seismic twin live sets recorded just prior to his six year hiatus
column3: Agharta and Pangea-- were mired in electronic noise and chugging rhythm. He put a wah- wah on his trumpet and claimed that he wanted the instruments to be indistinguishable from one another. The move was toward collectivity in sound
column4: an idea Miles associated with African music (certainly refracted through the lens of Hendrix's guitar).

column1: Coltrane
column2: canonized as a saint by at least one church I know of in San     Francisco
column3: moved in the absolute opposite direction: toward singularity--     the transcendence of his own searching voice above all else. Even the     symbology with which the two musicians presented their music moved in     opposite directions.  Davis presented himself in a kind of a primeval     paganism
column4: as the Dark Magus-- the Sorcerer-- and cloaked his songs in a tellurian rhetoric: earth and evil. Coltrane
column6: adopted an almost Christian lexicon after the psalmic perfection of A Love Supreme; he fancied his archangelic music a kind of personal liturgy.

column1: And after a restless life of continuous ascension
column2: Coltrane's final album reached the cosmic heights of Interstellar Space. Now
column3: we can debate volumes on the merits and flaws of Interstellar Space
column4: an album     stripped of the legendary quartet
column5: featuring only Coltrane and Rasheed Ali     on drums. We can suffice to say that it was 'Trane's nod to the music of     the spheres
column6: and that it is accordingly difficult and complex. The idea of     covering this album
column7: also suffice to say
column8: is lunacy.  However
column9: free- jazz drummer Gregg Bendian of Interzone and guitarist Nels Cline have attemptd to do just that.

column1: Now
column2: I'm ever wary of the phrase ""plays the music of
column3: and it can be excused     when we're talking about Gershwin or Bacharach
column4: but the idea of someone else     playing John Coltrane's music is basically paradox. Surprisingly enough
column5: Cline and Bendian make the right decisions: they play in the spirit of John     Coltrane: ascendant
column6: noisy
column7: searching and free.  Cline's guitar- playing     offers such non- stop feedback- soaked freakout that it almost approaches     the sound of a continuously connecting modem.  Bendian's drumming is     similarly abstract but manages to always sound like creative
column8: ballsy rock drumming rather than the nimble coloring of Ali.

column1: In reality
column2: this album owes more to John McLaughlin's Mahavishnu Orchestra     and the great '70s fusion that Miles himself inspired than any sound John     Coltrane ever produced. (I can't help but think of the guitar/ drum duo of     John McLaughlin & Billy Cobham rather than 'Trane and Ali.) But there is no     doubt that the album is inspired or

column1: Interstellar Space Revisited is a forward- thinking
column2: millennial     interpretation of Coltrane's later music. But the frontiers of jazz were so     wildly transgressed a mere five years after Coltrane's death
column3: and the album     seems to constantly reference that first flowering of electrified jazz that     occurred under the shadow of Miles rather than Coltrane. Nevertheless
column4: the     album is angularly beautiful in its own right and
column5: for all the noise and     tweaks
column6: there is indeed a sense of humility in the playing. After all
column7: how     can you ape the spiritual questing of another? At best
column8: you can ascend to     modest heights and then humbly thank St. John Coltrane for achieving those     grand astronomical reaches for the rest of us.  And Cline and Bendian have     achieved this
column9: noisily
column10:
but with grace.

Icelandic lore tells of the Hidden People who live in the crags and lava of jagged mountains.

column2: the Hidden People come in many forms.  The tiny

column1: blómaálfar dwell in flower blossoms while the common búaálfar reside on farms.  Even in this
modern age of cellphones and helicopters

column1: are still out there somewhere.  Construction workers even curve roads around rumored dwellings

Norse mythology and a breathtaking raw landscape explains much of it.  The indigenous music

The album begins submerged.  Sonar pings echo from liquid feedback
but crushing you like an ocean in its volume.  A cathedral organ moans.  Wire brushes drum
in a sinking pace.  A violin bow saws open the maw of massive guitar

the blue alien from The Fifth Element). The song ends in an accelerating heartbeat
that breaks into palpitations. Sound fizzles out. You've died.

instruments flutter around skeletal drums and sepulchral bass.  This music tethers to

As any one of the ambivalent trust fund babies
column3: and other sordid mouse jockeys with the spare time to read my reviews will     be able to attest: I like country rock.  I can't help it.  Raised in     a sea of Neil Young's rumbling rockers and rustic ballads
column4: country rock     seems like the natural state of music to me
column5: with other genres and subgenres     bastardizing its bedrock and branching out into the expanse.  As flawed as     I have to admit that feeling is
column6: I have no control over myself. I'm a sucker for the harmonica. Play me a mandolin and I'm as pliable and receptive as a divorcee in the back seat of her stockbroker's BMW. (My friends tell me it's quite a sight.)

column1: So
column2: I should love the latest Old 97's release
column3: Fight Songs. The band's named after a train
column5: and after their clever and tuneful Too Far to Care
column6: I waited with baited breath for its follow     up.  And waited.  And waited.  Finally-- and mysteriously covered in Bolivian     stamps-- the package from Pitchfork arrived.  Tossing the remainder of the     package's contents somewhere I hope to locate again soon
column7: I grabbed Fight Songs and shoved it in the stereo.

column1: Now
column2: when the latest breed of country rockers sprung out of who- knows- where     in the late '80s
column3: the critics occasionally called it ""insurgent country
column6: on rare occasions
column7: even ""country punk.""     But what emanated from my speakers that fateful night was neither insurgent     nor alt
column8: and it was most certainly a far cry from punk. But enough of what Fight Songs isn't.

column1: What Fight Songs amounts to is a collection of insipidly pleasant
column2: well- executed pop songs of some distant relation to country and
column4: a     harrowing disappointment.  Gone is Rhett Miller's quirky wordplay-- it's     replaced with platitudes aplenty.  Miller's vocals
column5: a welcome respite over the edgier tunes gracing Too Far to Care
column6: abets the band's pop     intentions
column7: only exacerbating matters.  The album's opener
column8: ""Jagged
column9: kicks     off with a craggy Crazy Horse- lite riff before dissolving into a toothless     wonder
column10: setting the table for what follows.  It's not so much that the songs     fail as a result of their pure pop sweetness
column11: but rather they miss their marks in their size. These are very small pop songs. A great majority of the album (""Oppenheimer"" and ""Nineteen"" are prime examples here) is almost unbearably earnest.

column1: Late last year
column2: I fiddled as Rome burned.  While other music writers decried     the industry mergers and feared that the rosters that would inevitably be     cut as a result
column3: I naively assumed that the indie labels would pick up     anything of worth.  Now
column5: I sit here with this shoddy Old     97's disc-- diligently packaged and delivered by Elektra Records-- while     the latest Luna release sits in import limbo.  Well
column6:
at least the three bucks I get for trading this sucker in will help defray that import sticker price...

There's something really strange about Jimi Tenor that it's hard to put a finger on. He performs his songs completely straight-faced
column4: like he's     as serious about his work as Sting is about saving whales.  But the songs
column6: are just too damned weird for there not to be some tongue- in- cheek value intended.

column1: Organism was released earlier this year on the revered electronic label Warp Records
column2: home to such forward-thinking auteurs as Squarepusher
column6: and Two Lone Swordsmen.  And as     different as this album is from the rest of Warp's roster
column7: it somehow     belongs-- like Neil Hamburger on Drag City
column8: Guided By Voices on TVT
column9: or gospel diva Thornetta Davis on Sub Pop.

column1: Tenor's bizarre blend of earnest
column6: Jarvis Cocker delivery is truly disturbing.  Is he serious or     just bein' goofy?  It's impossible to know.  But when the skinny
column7: thick- rimmed-      glasses- wearin' Warhol lookalike lustfully whispers ""I wanna be the     taxi driver who takes you home tonight/ I wanna be every customer in the     diner where you work
column8: before belting out ""'Cause I wanna work to make you     love me
column9: his computer nerd image comes off as simultaneously sexy and Triple X sleazy.

column1: Tenor is at his most charming on Organism's slinky soul tracks
column2: especially ""Love and Work"" and ""Sleep"" which both draw heavily from     modern ghetto R&B; beats and jazz flute solos from late '60s Quincy Jones     records.  But Tenor's act is far from gimmicky.  The leadoff track
column3: ""Total     Devestation"" and ""Year of Apocalypse"" are thunderous
column5: while ""Xinotepe Heat"" sounds like a cross between Alice Coltrane's Journey in Satchidananda
column6: Jan Hammer's ""Theme from 'Miami Vice'"" and the soundtrack to the second level of ""Sonic the Hedgehog 2.""

column1: The album's two low points come with the grading ""Muchmo
column2: a song that     features a sterile
column3: programmed electronic beat and a vocoder-enhanced     voice-- presumably Tenor's-- endlessly repeating the words ""Much more     psychedelic/ Than any of the drugs
column5: whose mind-     numbing repetition of the phrase ""Give me something good that'll feed     my soul/ 'Cause you need some serious love to stay happy"" is a little     irritating.  Luckily
column6: these songs are spaced far enough apart on the     disc that they don't really interfere much with the overall quality     of the record.  Besides
column7: the brilliant ""My Mind
column8: with its sultry     sax solo and Talking Heads-influenced background chorus
column9: and the     dark futurism of the album's closing number
column10: ""City Sleeps
column11: are perhaps some of the most innovative and original in the entire Warp catalog.

column1: Organism would be an awesome listen on a rainy Spring night in Tokyo or while cruising Main Street in downtown Anoka
column2: Minnesota on     any given August night in 1983.  Whatever the case
column3: its magic cannot     be truly appreciated while the sun's up.  Reserve for New Year's Eve     Party

column1: Dead Bees on a Cake isn't exactly akin to the incidental soundtrack

lifetime opening- for- Kitaro circuit. But hey.
Having been a member of synth- rock pioneers Japan
natural that Sylvian would eventually record with someone authentically
Japanese. Good thing he decided to work with arranging/ composing genius
Ryuichi Sakamoto
column4: Yoko Ono or nasty ol' Yamatsuka Eye.

column1: Dead Bees on a Cake is nothing less than a continuation of Sylvian's
eclectic series of genre- hopping solo albums-- the best of which is
probably his first major collaborative effort with Sakamoto
Brilliant Trees.
When you're like Sylvian-- able to attract the likes of Robert Fripp
(who plays on 1993's God's Monkey)
and have them function as your sidemen-- you know you've finally become that
semi- obscure but critically- acclaimed rock enigma you've always dreamed of
becoming
column2: right? Even Marc Ribot decides to contribute some inimitable

column1: guitar work on this latest album
his busy schedule playing with every single musician in New York City.
Dead Bees leads off with the spare
and gives some foreshadowing of what's to come. Ribot's traditional jazz
octave- playing shares space with abbreviated flugelhorn parts
tape- looped guitar ornamentation (the funk- inflected churn of ""God Man""
suggests Mitchell Froom could have had his busy paws on the mixing board at
some point
column2: although there's no documented proof).  But in many cases

column1: a guitar and vocals are apparently enough to satisfy Sylvian.  For instance
on ""Dobro #1
column2: Bill Frisell handles the dobro duties while Sylvian simply

column1: sings.  Or you may get an arrangement like the one on ""Pollen Path
consisting of slide guitar
Each track comes together in the sense that no one instrument or effect is
ever really featured over another-- and that includes Sylvian's low
vocals. His vocal cadences fit snugly around whatever instrumentation
happens to be floating about. The songs also benefit from Sakamoto's
arranging expertise
column2: in that he seems to know exactly where and when to

column1: add the odd orchestral quirk
string or brass arrangement.
Sylvian's intrepid
column2: near- subliminal use of samples proves to be an

column1: approach far beyond the grasp of most shameless sample- happy ""progressive""
groups. He extracts bits and pieces from the Mahavishnu Orchestra
John Lee Hooker and Charles Brown's 1946 Cash Box award- winning single
""Driftin' Blues
column2: slowly and subtly interspersing the sampled contents into

column1: a song's framework. ""Driftin' Blues"" and samples of Hooker's ""I'm Wanderin'""
serve as the ostensible basis for Sylvian's unorthodox interpretation
of simple blues on ""Midnight Sun."" Pretty heady stuff it is
compared to the output of millions of musically- illiterate con-men who
steal huge chunks of old Motown hits or spy- movie themes and add a trip-hop
beat
column2: just before insisting that the result be hailed as serious work of art.

column1: Talvin Singh makes an indispensable contribution
raga rhythms on ""Krishna Blue"" and ""All My Mother's Names.""  The latter

column2: as it unleashes primal screams and

column1: experiences fits of electronic epilepsy. Other extra- terrestrial sound
samples fade in and out
out of control in something resembling the opening credits of ""The Twilight

Sadly
column2: Dead Bees on a Cake will most likely be received like every

column1: other David Sylvian solo project-- that is
America and a maybe few eyebrow raisings in Europe. True
Japan fans expecting another Gentlemen Take Polaroids
Sex
column2: this may at first sound to you like stuff you'd only listen to

column1: during an Oriental massage or a Calgon bath.  But don't be fooled. Sylvian's
lyrics are poetic and rarely dull

musical vision makes it pretty tough to dismiss as mere new age pap.

In the Pitchfork tradition of groundbreaking review styles
column2: I present you with the Always- Right Critomatic album review.  Simply scroll to the review you want to read-- the opinion that you
column4: wants to hear-- and proceed. We here in the Pitchfork labs are always striving towards innovations for the future.

column1: Pro-Mogwai:

You slip on your headphones...  Guitar chords twist down from lavender skies in slithering fibers and attach to your goose- bumped skin.  With each upward strum from the plaintive second album from Mogwai
column2: these delicate cables tug you heavenward-- they're soft tugs
column3: paced and patient.   As you ascend further into the clouds you can make out the ground below you.  The Scottish Highlands
column5: bubbles in pillowy hills.  Green grass hills filled with warm fat
column6: feathers
column7: and the carefully dug tunnels of fairies and elves roll to the sea
column8: where they suddenly drop off in marble cliffs
column9: wet from the spray of slapping waves.   A storm is brewing in the distance.  Thunder rumbles.   Mogwai's music is weather.  Its landscape
column10: stunning in its simplicity and reduncancy. Come On Die Young develops in one long movement
column11: a sparse symphony of indie. You can follow its pattern like a weatherman charts flows from high pressure to low pressure.

column1: Unlike Mogwai's last album
column2: which constantly shifted from loud loud to quiet quiet
column3: Come On Die Young builds tension over eight and a half songs before erupting in the white noise of ""Ex-Cowboy
column5: the latter being the only respite from restraint for the riffheads.  But it's the album's title track
column6: carrying the record's only vocal
column7: sung in soft sighs
column8: that pulls apart your heart like string cheese
column9: muscle fiber by muscle fiber.

column1: Like a bottle of fine wine
column2: Mogwai is not intended to be ingested on every humdrum day you live. It's not to be played as you drive to the Target to pick up some plastic adhesive hooks. Keep Come On Die Young on a cedar rack in a damp basement. Reserve it for thunderstorms and candlelight. Its open spaces and moments of silence are meant to be filled with raindrops and whispers of awe.

column1: Con-Mogwai:
Fo'ckin bollocks! Where's the rock? Listening to Mogwai's Come On Die Young excites as much as toasting white bread with a magnifying glass in the sun on a partially- cloudy day. Here's the thing
column2: if Mogwai weren't from the UK
column3: no one would give a rat's arse about them.

column1: I call this phenomenon the ""3 Colours Red Effect
column2: which states that any British band that plays a style of music that is completely overdone in America
column3: but not particularly in the UK
column4: they will achieve success in their native land.  Would 3 Colours Red's brand of polished grunge sell any more than a new Gruntruck or Paw record?  Call up Sony and find out.  Likewise
column5: would Mogwai's brand of third generation post- Slint instrumentals raise anyone's attention outside of those few Chicago college kids who still listen to Spiderland religiously?   In the UK
column6: Mogwai open for the Manic Street Preachers (who are amazingly big in the UK) and headline festivals.  If they were from Urbana
column7: Illinois they'd be on Quarterstick Records at best
column8: opening for June of 44 at the Blind Pig.

column1: Come On Die Young's most exciting track
column3: sounds like an unfinished Sweep the Leg Johnny song (i.e.
column6: more complex tempo changes
column7: etc.)
column8: which
column9: while pretty decent
column10: is not enough to get you a spot opening for Everclear in the States. This is not to say that fame is an essential element to good music. I'm just pointing out that Mogwai could perhaps be the most over- hyped indie rock band in the world. There are much better bands doing the same thing from the back of vans across the US.

column1: Young Team
column3: painted in bolder strokes. Feedback and riffs burst unexpectedly from beautiful melodies. I found myself hunching over the boombox waiting for Come On Die Young to develop. Then my back got sore. For an instrumental album
column4: the playing is not mathy or complex enough to evoke interest.

column1: Halvorsen's pulsing
column2: tugging basslines and MacLachlan's murderously precise

column2: strangled scream. The songs themselves range from

column1: the lulling
column2: peaceful 8+ minutes of ""Tide"" and the comparatively poppy

World"" and ""Two Stars.""
Parker's lyrics on Solar 3 are more concerned with human relationships
than interstellar ones.  And the fact that Parker is actually singing about--
rather than merely alluding to-- real people and emotions
human warmth to the otherwise rather chilly proceedings.
While the fact is that most Bailter Space songs don't amount to much more than

the whole package has the ability to transport the unsuspecting listener into

Well
column3: we already know what to expect: a

attitudinal Nashville greaseballs that grab us by the belt loops and shake

Upon first listen

column2: if Mike Ness and Co. had turned to coffee and Jolt

Johnny Ramone chord changes like he was born to do it. And he even takes a

The band also boasts that undeniable Arthur Fonzarelli fashion sense: the

duck-tail hair-sculpting thing going on
ear
column2: the requisite array of arrow- through- the- heart tattoos

column1: characters.  Oh
column2: and for all you truck-stop chauvinists out there

column1: load of the chick bass player-- the busty stereotypical blond with the

column2: tight t-shirt and painted-on patent leather pants. Looks like

column1: she might enjoy bouncing around a lot on stage.
The Teen Idols' approach to songwriting is every bit as obvious as their
image and band moniker would suggest. So I'll mercifully spare you any
unnecessary bullshit analysis.  As predictable and intentionally
unoriginal as this punk-pop with a bubblegum center is
still direct you to a few ""standout"" tracks. Take the title cut

And ""Insanity Plea"" is powered by the Idols' characteristic muscle-chord

(and especially comical) ditties about the Information Age's mechanically-dependent
robo-children
column2: ""Virtual Loser"" and ""Test Tube Teens."" One of the things that sets

column1: the Idols apart from your average
testosterone-fueled grease-rock outfit is a much-needed dose of
estrogen in the vocals-- big-boned
combines with the fellas for some of the strongest guy/gal harmonizing
around.
Unfortunately
column3: with its one-dimensional slant on punk

column1: is capable of yielding too much of a good thing. Some of these three-chord
pedal- to- the- metal stomps have plenty of acceleration
melodic line or hook that really burns rubber in the subconscious. And I'm
not sure why so many bands
column3: get a such a chuckle out

column1: of tacking on pointless filler towards the end of a particular disc.
Here they include silly-ass studio bloopers and other moronic chatter
during the final ten or so minutes of the album. I guess it must be some
desperate need to communicate just how freaky
stoned in a recording studio can be.
The Teen Idols have enough up-yours attitude and sense of fun to be
would imagine
column2: a truly great live band. And now that the old guard of punks

column1: like Social Distortion and the Ramones have aged and petered out
young fogies like Green Day have become self-righteous acoustic-plucking
auteurs
column2: we could certainly do worse than a little Teen Idolatry.

Six months after handing over his first cup- a- noodle- bespattered rent check to his landlord
then-unknown local DJ Luke Slater picked up on Vogel's experimental sound and spread the word
around to such an extent that abstract dance maven Colin Dale was soon dropping Vogel's ""Aux
Culture"" DAT into his sets. Dave Clarke followed by signing Vogel to his Magnetic North label
and the pair combined Clarke's jazz-imbued rhythm programming with Vogel's passion for
outlandish analog noise. By 1994

experimentalism (and Germanness) of its techno releases
Understand and the disorientating live and improvised knob tweak-a-thon Specific

The moment I saw the packaging I knew something was up: the cover art features
the sort of computer punch- card font favored by two- bit electronics repair shops
and sketchy medical equipment supply companies-- the sort of font that calls to mind
images of dusty industrial shelving and the shells of old daisy- wheel printers
covered with the sticky residue of dried Mountain Dew.  I fiddled nervously with the
disc the whole way home
column2: terrified that my Friends had joined the minions of

column1: Electronica. When I got the disc playing
column3: I was met not with some

column1: ridiculous skittering beat
column2: but with a moog and an organ

column1: for a minute and a half in a way which immediately laid my fears to rest.
Atardecer
column2: the Friends of Dean Martinez's Knitting Factory debut

column1: incorporate a level of technology that I had previously thought irreconcilable to
their sound.  But there are no MIDI sequences here
just the rough waveforms of moogs
column2: harmoniums and weird analog effects: in short

column1: the type of technology which actually belongs on dusty industrial shelving
alongside the shells of old daisy- wheel printers.  It hasn't replaced Bill Elm's
haunting steel or desert sensibility
column2: but instead has added a layer of texture which

column1: allows Atardecer to continue in the vein of previous Friends of Dean
Martinez albums without simply retreading old ground.
The opening track
""Quickening
column2: is no doubt the first Friends recording to be completely devoid of

column1: guitar
column2: and it's just plain pretty.  Likewise
column3: the record's closer is likely the only

column1: Friends song on which Elm desn't play a lick
guitar and organ duties and laying them all over an expected beatbox.  In between are
nine tunes ranging from the straight- ahead band sound of ""Ethchlorvynol"" to the
album's highlight ""Casa Mila
column2: whose nylon string guitar and harpsichord eventually

column1: give way to a background of spacious washes and bleeps.
Ultimately Atardecer reveals the extent to which the Friends of Dean Martinez
is really Bill Elm's project
column2: presenting itself as a cohesive whole in a way the band's

column1: two preceding albums have not quite managed.  And the introduction of some new toys has
helped head off the fear that these guys might find themselves the victims of the
misconception that they're merely a lounge revival novelty.  These songs are too sincere

and just plain too pretty for that.

who fashions folk songs with a plausibility and earnestness which belies his age.  Molina wields

Many of these tracks feature remarkable backing vocals by the gifted Edith Frost which imbues

I'm a Looper
He's a Looper
She's a Looper
We're a Looper
Wouldn't you like to be a Looper
Stuart David of Belle and Sebastian has handed a DIY book on home sampling out to any and all
kids with a Casio keyboard and a tape recorder. He wants them to turn everyday life into a
story set to music. And to quote something I read somewhere more than twice
is.""  David makes me happy because he writes happy songs.  Hmm... I guess I should have more to say
on the subject.  Well
column2: let's put it like this: David notices things and takes pleasure in them.

column1: He's someone who could sit on the front porch with a ray of sunlight touching his toes and
realize that it was good.
The songs on Up a Tree don't wander far from the backyard. Actually
even leave the treehouse. There's one that tells the story of him and his wife Karn (who
performs the visual half of Looper... adding slides and movies to their shows) and the letter-
writing that led to their here and now.  None of these are actually the best songs ever written
but they're fun.  And the honesty with which David presents his stories along with the stripped
down and earnest 'electronica' backing them is far fresher than pretty much anything you can
hear on the radio today. I'd like to go to a club (I guess that means I have to go to a club)
and shake my all to any of them
column2: but I'd rather just sit in the grass and listen.

column1: ""The Ballad of Ray Suzuki"" professes David' belief that we all can be Loopers. Most people
probably won't follow his lead
column2: although I could envision some sort of folk-hop movement

column1: starting up on the college campuses. Drum machine
column2: anyone? Care for a tape loop

column1: Sample yourself. Sample your friends. Just don't sample the Police or Led Zeppelin and

perform rap Karaoke over them. No one would ever buy that.

Last time we caught up with Damien Jurado
column2: he was cracking that wicked whip they call

column1: the pop song.  On his 1997 Sub Pop debut
that resonated with joy and sorrow while keeping things generally upbeat and excessively
catchy.  But there was one thing keeping the man down: he couldn't sing a lick.  His
cracking
column3: off-key tenor was so painfully prevalent that it made the songs a

column1: bit difficult to listen to.  A serious shame
Ave. S.-- to quote that old legend of insanity
column2: Wesley Willis-- whooped on a llama's ass.

column1: Two years have passed since that pretty excellent offering
Rehearsals for Departure
column2: an album that improves on its predecessor in every

column1: department.  The guy's vocals are the most immediately noticable difference-- he's
still no Tony Bennett
column2: but he's sounding great these days.  On top of that

column1: a brand new dance in the songwriting aisle.  Jurado's new songs seem far more
inspired by the introspective stylings of Springsteen or Neil Young than smiley
pop stars.
But Jurado hasn't abandoned the pop song.  Tracks like ""Honey Baby"" and ""Letters and
Drawings"" show he's got a knack for penning unforgettable
Rehearsals for Departure is
tales of longing and regret.  ""Ohio"" is an elaborate and painfully sad tale of a girl
deciding to return home years after being kidnapped by her father.  ""Curbside"" is
a surprisingly convincing post- breakup number that recalls those glorious first days
of love. And ""Love the Same"" might be the loneliest number that he'll ever do.
Of course
column2: the thing that makes these tracks truly outstanding are Jurado's romantic

column1: and poetic lyrics-- the way he can make the most simple action sound so dramatic.
On ""Ohio
column3: ""She stands on the sidewalk/ Just waving at taxis/ Like horses

column1: and parades in passing.""  In that line
column2: he recalls the simplicity of childhood while

column1: tackling the frustrations of adulthood without even trying.  It's lyrics like these
along with the occasional simple flourishes (like female background vocals
orchestration and simple harmonies) that really make Rehearsals for Departure

a really great record.

If you've never pondered the source of the rat-at-tat-tat boom-boom ascending

column1: from darkened alleyways
column2: know that these sounds emanate not from gunfire

column1: from an unregistered Liverpudlian Clinic whose surgeons engage in dissections
of the by-gone underground influences of America.  The execution is primitive
but its intent is logical.  The music is elemental
ancestral types that serve as influences to their rough methodology.  But a
balanced rationale clearly governs Clinic's menacing aural approach.  The song
title ""I.P.C. Subeditors Dictate Our Youth"" signifies a blatant call to action
against the modern-day bureaucratic mind-control that pervades youth markets
both above and below ground.  It indicates a deviant sense of purpose that more
scrupulous medical practitioners lack.
The surgeon's table has seen the inhumanly savage cut-and-paste of <i>White
Light/White Heat-era Velvet Underground with the rhythmic assault of Hal
Blaine under Phil Spector's direction.  The screams are Spector's own-- the
sonic equivalent of studied horror from witnessing organs being spilled upon
the sterile tile floor.
The technique is concerned with brutal distortions of aesthetics.  ""Porno""
aches and moans orgasmically to a warbled throbbing of keyboard and guitar.
It's topped with indecipherable vocal incantations meant to terrorize those
that have trouble grasping the deconstruction of rhythm within the context
of terrible sex.
An insidious affinity for indirect discourse is discernible in the otherwise
unintelligible vocal approach.  ""D.P."" and ""D.T."" are violent odes to sonic
aggression
column2: exemplified by the less sophisticated punk rockers of the '60s

column1: and '70s.  ""Punk
column2: having become a loaded political term

column1: the same way an anesthetic is administered for inducing numbness in wounded
patients.
The knives-out approach of these medical knaves belies the sadistic glee with
which they patch their subjects together.  The gruesome freshness of their
product indicates a fruitful decomposition of influences from within-- the
appropriation of life-blood from yesterday's walking dead imbues their macabre
creations with mortal verisimilitude and stylistic panache.  Shrouded in a
skeletal grasp of melody
column2: the most shocking prospect is the widespread acceptance

column1: of their unsound practices
column2: and the slow unfolding of their message through the

column1: easily misconstrued language of rhythm and dissonance.  Subversion has never

sounded so palpably suicidal.

"|1514.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/1514-clinic/|8.0|S. Murray

As stifling as things could get in Baptist country
Matt Johnson seemed to understand our isolation
indictment of our parents' sham Christian mores. He made it okay to revel
in our non-believing misfit gloom. His aetheistic gallows humor and cutting
social commentary was delivered with a bracing defiance. His songwriting
didn't induce the kind of feeble hopelessness that would normally lead a
bored
column2: confused suburban kid to lose it completely.

column1: Inhabiting a shadowy interzone between goth
Blue Soul manages to plumb depths that Robert Smith and Peter Murphy could
only lightly touch upon. Johnson delivers his kernels of realist wisdom in
a flat Gregorian monotone: ""100
column2: 000 people were burned/ I felt a pang of

column1: concern/ What are we waitin' for/ A message of hope/ From the Pope/ I think
he got shot as well.""  And what over-ponderous mope-rocker can't relate
to observations like this: ""When you hide in your bed/ And look in your
head/ You find you've gone deeper than you should/ It could be your
shallowness is your strength.""
In a sense
column2: the ghostly production values on Burning Blue Soul sound

column1: like fairly upstanding (and typical) 4AD fare: the isolated vocals
guitars wet with reverb
column2: the basslines slithering eerily along the nether

column1: regions of a song. Thick guitar hailstorms come and go.  Textures vacillate
from vaulted cathedrals of sound to barely discernible structures. ""The
River Flows East in Spring"" is built around little more than a deformed
keyboard hook and offbeat handclaps. There are no beginnings
or ends. Johnson completely shuns verse- chorus- verse predictability
and doesn't even find much need to tie down his songs with conventional
drumming or consistent backbeats.
Of course
column2: Johnson eventually lured ex-Smiths guitarist Johnny Marr into

column1: the studio for 1989's ground-breaking Mind Bomb. Marr brought a
richer and more grounded sound to Johnson's near- formless compositions.
The band's sound eventually evolved into the mellow New Order-ish pop of
1993's Dusk
column2: and took a detour with 1995's near-ridiculous batch

column1: of Hank Williams cover songs entitled Hanky Panky.
So
column2: here's a novel idea for all you alienated

column1: youngsters: try trading in those ridiculous Marylin Manson CDs
whatever artillery your NRA-member father bought you for Christmas. Cleanse
your tortured souls in the church of Matt Johnson.  Take heed
little doom-obsessed freaks
column2: Manson's music will eventually make you

column1: open a vein-- or worse
column2: open fire on your peers.  But most of all

column1: that Manson's crusade is merely to open your little pocketbooks and swindle
you out of those hard-earned weekly allowances. Take a listen to The The's
Burning Blue Soul. The lovable folks at 4AD reissued it just for you.
Maybe it'll even open a few of your minds to more pacific and productive
possibilities of expressing all that pent-up hate.

The concept of late work isn't invoked in too many record reviews

of pop stars as artists-- for good reason really

column1: about popular music would prefer to think otherwise-- and ideas common to other forms of
criticism very rarely find their way into rock reviews.
Which is as it should be.  Still

column1: any pursuit which spans a couple decades

column2: ""I just liked him better when...""  Sure

Neil Hamburger's third comedy release is a desperate affair
sad sack such as America's Funnyman.  Hamburger-- aka Gregg Turkington--
takes his routine to Kuala Lumpur
before karaoke time.  Too bad nobody in the audience speaks or
understands English.
It's a broad setup knocked down with Hamburger's usual patheticness.
(Sample joke:  ""How many Spice Girls does it take to screw in a
lightbulb?  Well
column4: and I'm sure any day now

column1: it'll be down to three.  Uh
column2: huhhhh..."")  Early on in the show

column1: Hamburger realizes no one in the crowd speaks English and
his manager and right- hand man Art Huckman flees the scene in a huff.
With no one left to lean on
column2: Neil opens up about his past gigs

column1: performing at Amway conventions
something called ""Montezuma's Revenge.""
Is it funny?  Not really
column2: but that's the point.  <i>Left for Dead in

column1: Malaysia is forty minutes of flop sweats
column2: so much so that you might

column1: feel moist after listening.  As usual
column2: the joke is on Hamburger; is there

column1: a bigger loser on the planet than this guy? Yes
but the flat routine on Left for Dead may have you thinking
otherwise.  Hamburger (or Turkington
column2: to be more precise) hits the

column1: desperation nail square on the head
Funnyman both fared a lot better. I'm sure that there's going to be
another Neil Hamburger album-- the stage is easily set for this loser to
sink even lower-- and those who enjoyed the previous albums will enjoy
Left for Dead more than the folks who don't get the joke. But there
aren't really any jokes on this album
column2: just a series of empty shells and

column1:
failed observations... classic Hamburger.
